text:
WINTER SPORTS IN SWITZERLAND

CHAPTER
I

THE SUN-SEEKER

There is an amazingly silly proverb which
quite mistakenly tells us that “seeing is believing.” The most ordinary
” The most ordinary conjurer at a village entertainment will prove the falsity of this
the falsity of this saying. For who has not seen one of these plausible mountebanks put a
e mountebanks put a watch into a top-hat, and, after clearly smashing it into a thousand
it into a thousand pieces with a pestle, stir up the disintegrated fragments with a spoon
gments with a spoon and produce an omelette? Or who is so unacquainted with the affairs of
with the affairs of the village schoolroom at Christmas as not to have seen a solid
o have seen a solid billiard-ball or a lively canary squeezed out of the side of a friend’s
side of a friend’s head? Such phenomena are by no means rare, and occur periodically all
ur periodically all over England. The observer’s eyes have told him that he has seen such
at he has seen such things, and the verb “to see” is merely a compendious expression to
dious expression to indicate that on the evidence of your eyes such or such a phenomenon has
ch a phenomenon has actually occurred. But no one believes that the disintegrated watch has
ntegrated watch has become an omelette though ocular evidence—seeing—insists that it has. It

sts that it has. It was a conjuring trick. And this leads me to the consideration of the
phenomena on which this whole book is based.

For High Alpine resorts in winter are a conjuring trick of a
glorious and luminous kind. Our commonsense, based on experience, tells
n experience, tells us that ice is cold, but is melted by heat; and that snow is wet; and
at snow is wet; and that unless you put on a greatcoat when the thermometer registers frost,
er registers frost, you will feel chilly; and that if you frequently fall down in the snow
ll down in the snow you will be wet through, and if you do not change your clothes when you
ur clothes when you return home you will catch a cold. All these things are quite obvious,
are quite obvious, and he who does not grant them as premises to whatever conclusion we may
r conclusion we may happen to base on them, is clearly not to be argued with, but soothed
d with, but soothed and comforted like a child or taken care of like a lunatic. But High
a lunatic. But High Alpine winter resorts give, apparently, ocular disproof of all these
sproof of all these obvious statements, and those who go out to these delectable altitudes
electable altitudes in favourable seasons see (which is ocular evidence) every day and all
) every day and all day the exact opposite of these primitively simple prepositions
simple prepositions regularly and continually taking place. They sit in the sun, when they
the sun, when they are tired of skating, and see that though a torrid luminary beats down
luminary beats down on the frozen surface, burning and browning the faces of their friends,
s of their friends, the ice remains perfectly dry and unmelted; they trudge through snow,
rudge through snow, and find that they are not wet; they see the thermometer marking
thermometer marking anything up or down to thirty degrees of frost, and go out coatless and
go out coatless and very likely hatless, and are conscious only of an agreeable and bracing
reeable and bracing warmth; they go ski-ing and all day are smothered in snow, and yet
ed in snow, and yet return dry and warm and comfortable to their hotels, and do not catch
s, and do not catch any cold whatever. Shakespeare once made an allusion of some kind (I
ion of some kind (I cannot look all through his plays to find it) about hot ice, meaning to

hot ice, meaning to employ a nonsensical expression. But it is the most striking testimonial
to the magnificence
to the magnificence of his brain that all he ever wrote meant something, although, as in

ng, although, as in this instance, he designed it not to. For without doubt he was alluding
to what appears to occur at St. Moritz or Mürren.

But it is all a conjuring trick, or so these altitudinists are
disposed to think when they return home to the dispiriting chills of a
iriting chills of a normal February in England, and find that when the thermometer marks 45°
ermometer marks 45° or thereabouts they shiver disconsolately in the clemming cold. Even
clemming cold. Even when they were out in Switzerland they hardly believed what appeared to
ed what appeared to be happening, for they found that if the weather changed, and instead of
ged, and instead of the windless calm, or a light north-wind, the Föhn-wind blew from the
-wind blew from the south-west, warm and enervating, then, in proportion as the thermometer
as the thermometer mounted, they felt increasingly cold. All these things, though they
things, though they thought they saw and felt them, were of the nature of a conjuring trick,
a conjuring trick, and they never, after their return to the lowlands, really believed
ds, really believed them. It was obviously impossible that they could have felt warm and
have felt warm and dry, after being rolled in the snow. It must have been an illusion,
e been an illusion, capable of immediate disproof if they now went out without a coat, or
without a coat, or sat down on a snowy London pavement. A pleasant illusion, no doubt, but
sion, no doubt, but clearly an illusion. It was like the omelette emerging from the top-hat,

g from the top-hat, into which a watch had, only a moment before, been placed and
pestled.

And if those who think they have experienced these phenomena, which
so clearly contradict the most elementary laws of Nature, cannot fully
ature, cannot fully believe in them when they re-enter the chilly spring of England, still

g of England, still less do those who have not experienced them find it possible even to
simulate credulity when the foolish Alpinist
he foolish Alpinist recounts them. I rather fancy that people who have never been to the
e never been to the high altitudes in winter, believe that all those who say they have done
say they have done so, and come back and tell their friends that sun does not melt ice, and

s not melt ice, and that snow is dry, and that ten degrees of frost is an agreeable
temperature to stroll about in without a coat, are in some sort of
are in some sort of inexplicable conspiracy. But the conspiracy is so widely spread now, and
ely spread now, and is still spreading so fast, that one’s remarks on the subject are
on the subject are received with politeness nowadays, though still with incredulity. Some
h incredulity. Some strange wandering of the wits has taken possession of the conspirators,
f the conspirators, who are otherwise harmless. And, such is the force with which their
ce with which their illusion holds them, and so anxious are they that credence should be
credence should be given to it, that they employ some sort of skin-dye to add completeness
to add completeness to their strange tales, and appear with brown hands and faces when they
and faces when they come back to the anæmic metropolis. They are clearly the victims of some
the victims of some obscure but infectious derangement of the brain, of which the chief
of which the chief symptoms are those strange illusions and an immense appetite.... And, as
ppetite.... And, as I have said, the victims of these illusions, before they have spent many
hey have spent many days in England, are already themselves wondering whether all these
g whether all these things really were so, or whether they were but the fabric of a pleasing

abric of a pleasing dream. But they make plans to dream again about the middle of the
ensuing autumn, and for the most part find that the vision is
that the vision is recapturable. It is all great nonsense; but if you take a suitable

you take a suitable ticket at a suitable time of the year, and go where that ticket will
allow you, the nonsense is found to be recurrent.

I do not know whether ice and snow, and all the forms of the “radiant
frost,” as Shelley calls it, are in themselves more
in themselves more beautiful than the spectacle, to which we are accustomed, of an unfrozen
med, of an unfrozen world, or whether it is merely because we are unused to the gleams and
d to the gleams and sparkle of these whitenesses, that we find them so entrancingly lovely.
ntrancingly lovely. It would be interesting, for instance, to ascertain whether an Esquimo
whether an Esquimo or other dweller in the Arctics accustomed to ice, would go into
ice, would go into ecstasies of admiration at the sight—shall we say—of Hyde Park Corner on
Hyde Park Corner on a moist warm day of September, when the roadway is swimming in a thick
swimming in a thick brown soup of mud, and gusts of tepid rain stream on the wind-swept
m on the wind-swept lamp-posts, thus supporting the idea that it is to the novelty of the
the novelty of the spectacle that the arousing of our appreciation is due. Certainly it
s due. Certainly it would be hard to say that anything in the world is more beautiful than a
re beautiful than a beech-tree in spring, or a crimson rambler in full flower, or glimpses
flower, or glimpses of the Mediterranean in a frame of grey-green olive-trees; and I am
ive-trees; and I am inclined to believe that it is partly the contrast which a sunny morning
ich a sunny morning in winter among the High Alps presents to all that a Londoner has known
Londoner has known or dreamed of hitherto that partly accounts for the ineffable
s for the ineffable impressions it never fails in producing on him. And to that we must add
to that we must add the exhilarating and invigorating effect of the still dry air, and the
ll dry air, and the sun that all day pours Pactolus over the gleaming fields. In such an air

lds. In such an air and in such a flood of light all our senses and perceptions are
quickened, the vitality of our organs is increased, and with the

eased, and with the wonderful feeling of bien-être which the conditions give, our
appreciation is kindled too. I always feel that it must have
l that it must have been on a frosty morning that David said: “I opened my mouth and drew in

y mouth and drew in my breath.” And perhaps on that day the cedars of Lebanon were covered
with the crystals of hoar-frost, and below the snowy

and below the snowy uplands the dim blue of the sea slept insapphirined at the bases of the
shining cliffs....

I lick the chops of memory, and go back in thought to the middle of
December, when, having previously determined not to go abroad till
t to go abroad till January, I hurriedly fly the country, like a criminal seeking to escape
l seeking to escape from the justice that is hot on the heels of a murderer. In such wise do
er. In such wise do I fly from my conscience—conscience, I may remark, is one of the things
s one of the things that everybody leaves behind when he goes to the High Alps: apparently
gh Alps: apparently it and other poisonous organisms, such as the bacillus of tuberculosis
lus of tuberculosis cannot exist in those altitudes—while below my breath I again register
th I again register the frequently broken vow that I will be at home again by the middle of
in by the middle of January at the latest. For indeed it seems impossible to tolerate London
to tolerate London any longer just now: the fogs have begun (these are the excuses with
re the excuses with which I seek to stay the protests of conscience, before I fly from it),
ore I fly from it), and for three days last week we lived in a thick and ominous twilight of
ominous twilight of dusky orange, tasting evilly of soot and sulphurous products. At
hurous products. At intervals a copper-coloured plate showed itself above the house roofs:
ve the house roofs: and, oh, to think that this mean metallic circle was indeed none other
s indeed none other than the hot radiant giant that in the happier climes was rejoicing to
es was rejoicing to run his course across the turquoise expanse of cloudless sky; that this
less sky; that this remote and meaningless object was the same that sparkled on dazzling
parkled on dazzling peak and precipice and turned the untrodden snows to sheets of diamond
o sheets of diamond dust. Then after three days of Stygian gloom the fog was dispersed by a
was dispersed by a shrewd and shrill north wind, and for a whole morning snow fell heavily,

snow fell heavily, which, as it touched the pavements and roadways of town more than
usually befouled by the fog, turned into a
fog, turned into a base and degrading substance resembling melting coffee-ice. The streets
ee-ice. The streets swam in the icy treacle of it, and motor-buses and other ponderous
and other ponderous vehicles cast undesired helpings of it at the legs of foot-passengers.
of foot-passengers. After this dispiriting day the weather changed again and a tepid
d again and a tepid south-westerly gale squealed through the streets. This was too much: I

his was too much: I bought a quantity of what is known as sermon-paper and two new
stylographs (this was another sop to conscience, and implied the
ce, and implied the intention of working out in Switzerland), made a few hasty and craven

ew hasty and craven arrangements on the telephone, and slid out of Charing Cross Station at
2.20 P.M. precisely next day, leaving
y next day, leaving conscience, like an abandoned wife, sobbing on the platform.

Now, while journeys, whether on land or sea, are apt to be but
tiresome businesses when they are undertaken at the call of some tedious
all of some tedious errand, they are vastly different affairs when they conduct the
en they conduct the traveller to joyful places and delectable pursuits. They are coloured by
hey are coloured by that which awaits him at the end of them (like the sweetness of sugar
sweetness of sugar permeating tea), and this particular progress is to me full of romantic
me full of romantic happenings. Dusk is already closing in before I reach the coast, and as
h the coast, and as the train halts on the hill above Folkestone, before being towed
before being towed backwards down to the harbour, I can see the lights beginning to twinkle
eginning to twinkle in the town and along the pier, which is surrounded by the great grey
d by the great grey immensity of the wave-flecked sea. A fine rain is falling dismally, and
lling dismally, and as I hurry across the slippery quay I am weighed down by an enormous
down by an enormous greatcoat (the pockets of which, I am sorry to say, are “salted” by

ay, are “salted” by various packets of cigarettes, which is why I wear it), and I stagger
under the weight of a suit-case, sooner than part with which
han part with which I would die. For the French or Swiss railway companies often (no doubt
ies often (no doubt with humorous intent) arrange that the traveller’s large luggage shall
large luggage shall not arrive for twenty-four hours or so after he has got to his
r he has got to his destination, and in less experienced years I have packed my boots and
packed my boots and skates in these detained trunks, and have been obliged to wait in savage
d to wait in savage inaction till the railway company has come to the end of its joke, just
d of its joke, just as one waits for the end of a long funny story. Not so now: my
ory. Not so now: my inseparable bag contains my large and cumbrous skate-shod boots as a
ate-shod boots as a first charge, and after they have been stowed, the mere necessities of
mere necessities of life, like clothes and dressing-case, as opposed to its joys, fill the
its joys, fill the rest. Even in the harbour the steamer sways with the back-wash of the
he back-wash of the heavy seas outside, and the mooring-ropes squeak and strain to its
k and strain to its unease. I stick in the narrow gang-plank that conducts in precipitous
ucts in precipitous incline to the deck (at least the corner of my suit-case does, which is

case does, which is part of my identity); a faint and awful smell of red plush sofas and
cold beef comes up from the stairs leading to the saloon; the
to the saloon; the tarpaulins, rigged up along the open passage between decks, flap

between decks, flap uneasily and are buffeted by the rain-soaked wind, and sailors hurry
about with white japanned tin objects in their hands....

All this sounds dismal and dispiriting enough, but such incidents, I
repeat, take their colour from that to which they lead the traveller,
lead the traveller, and when bound for Switzerland they are all haloed in a vague
l haloed in a vague pleasurable sense of excitement and romance. We put out on the turbulent
ut on the turbulent and windy sea, and as we round the end of the pier the whole boat
pier the whole boat shivers as a great white-headed wave strikes her. It is cold and wet on

is cold and wet on deck, but I have to linger there while the cliffs of my beloved native
land vanish into the grey of the
nto the grey of the swift on-coming night, and feel a perfect glow of enthusiasm at the idea
husiasm at the idea of not setting eyes on them again for another month or so (probably
nth or so (probably “so”: because conscience is now far away, perhaps still waiting at
ps still waiting at Charing Cross Station, in case I return by the next train), and already
train), and already I am beginning to be doubtful whether I really made a vow to be back by
a vow to be back by the middle of January. I pass rows of silent figures with closed eyes
es with closed eyes reclining on deck-chairs in the more sheltered corners: then the whole
ers: then the whole ship makes a scooping curtsey into the trough of a wave, and the water
wave, and the water pours sonorously on to the deck. Shrill whistles the wind in the
les the wind in the rigging, and a raucous steam-siren proclaims to all the traffic in the
the traffic in the Channel that we are off to Switzerland to skate, having left our
te, having left our consciences and the white cliffs of England behind us, and not caring

us, and not caring two straws, at this delightful moment, as to whether we ever see any of
them again.

I love the landing on the friendly shores of France, the waiting
while the ship is reluctantly coaxed sidling up to the pier, the hustle
he pier, the hustle to get through the custom-house and enter the warm, well-lit train. The
well-lit train. The foreign tongue is delightful to the ear: so, too, to the eye, the
oo, to the eye, the blue-bloused porters, and the unplatformed station, where the huge
ion, where the huge carriages tower high above one, emitting mysterious jets of steam. All
jets of steam. All is strange and new and delightful: the engine of unaccustomed build and
ccustomed build and outlandish voice, the grey upholstered compartments with their
artments with their hot-carpeted floors, the restaurant car with bottle-filled racks, where
filled racks, where presently I sit, part of a moving pageant of eating and drinking, as we
and drinking, as we shriek through stations and scour with ever-increasing velocity through

ng velocity through the darkness of a stormy night. At Laon mysterious jugglings take place:
another

take place:
another string of carriages is slowly shunted on to our train, to the
o our train, to the accompaniment of many cries of warning and encouragement and wavings of
ment and wavings of lanterns, and the buffers come home with a soft thud. We cast off our
ud. We cast off our tail, lizard-like, which is hauled away to travel divergently to Basle,
vergently to Basle, and soon we are thundering on again by the more direct route to Berne.
ect route to Berne. At some timeless hour a long halt is made, and compartment doors are

mpartment doors are flung open with the sonorous proclamation of the arrival of les
messieurs de la douane. Enter les messieurs, and at their
ieurs, and at their sesame bags fly open, and with strange staves they explore the hidden
explore the hidden recesses under the seats, in their nightly search for laces and spirits
r laces and spirits and cigarettes and all the contraband of peace. Soon this complimentary
this complimentary visit is over, the green shades are adjusted again over the lamps, and

over the lamps, and the vibration and rhythm of the racing wheels mingle and blend
themselves into the blurred edges of dream....

I do not wake until we are actually slowing down to enter Berne—that
city so justly famous for its bears, its President of this delectable
of this delectable republic, and its terrace from which the eager tourist vainly scans the
st vainly scans the impenetrable clouds which invariably screen from his view all possible
s view all possible glimpses of the mountains of the Oberland. Whenever I arrive at Berne it
arrive at Berne it is always a grey chilly morning, just above freezing point, so that the
point, so that the icy streets are half slush. At first this used to depress me with
to depress me with ominous forebodings of a thaw at the higher altitudes: now I know that
es: now I know that all the winter through it is always just thawing at Berne, and that the
Berne, and that the sky there always is heavily be-clouded. I think a sunny frosty morning

unny frosty morning there would cause me some considerable anxiety, for it would imply a
complete upset of climatic conditions, and midsummer might
and midsummer might be expected to hold its abhorred sway on the heights. So in perfect
ghts. So in perfect equanimity I climb back again into our train—heated to the temperature

In that wonderful poem “By the Fireside,” Robert Browning, in
speaking of the Alps in autumn, says:

“But at afternoon or almost eve

’Tis better; then the silence grows

To that extent you half believe

It must get rid of what it knows

Its bosom does so heave.”

And that which he weds to such lovely language is another of the
spells which the circle of the Alpine day and night weaves round us.
ht weaves round us. Only, I think, in winter the silence which he speaks of at evening, or,
of at evening, or, he might have added at night, is a thing incredible to those who, I may

it is broken by sounds of cowbells

n pine-woods, or of water hurrying from the heights. But in winter, on a still evening those
still evening those evidences of life are dumb, and yet the silence itself is pregnant with
lf is pregnant with vitality. At sunset the high tops burn in rose-coloured flame, and as
oured flame, and as the glory fades into the toneless velvet of the frosty sky, the stars in
y sky, the stars in their wheeling are of a brilliance utterly unknown to lower altitudes,
to lower altitudes, except perhaps where the desert lies fallow and dry beneath Egyptian

ome from the frozen fields, and doors are shut. Slowly the last rose-colour fades from the
lour fades from the peaks, and the stars brighten, and you hold your breath to hear the most
th to hear the most wonderful thing you have ever heard—utter stillness, that yet is
llness, that yet is strained almost to bursting point with the energies that make it, the

II
RINKS AND SKATERS

Something has already been said about the
swift-growing jungles of frost-flowers that so speedily cause the lakes
ily cause the lakes in Switzerland to be utterly useless for all purposes connected with
oses connected with skates. It suddenly strikes the writer that the inexperienced in these

ases out of ten the snow spoils the ice before it bears, and the frost-flowers spoil the

But at every Swiss resort there are rinks made, which render the

he construction and renovation of these rinks is most interesting, and ranks among the fine

e golf-links or the preparation of good wickets. These rinks are used for two purposes:
d for two purposes: skating, including bandy or ice hockey, and curling. I do not count
ing. I do not count ice-gymkhanas or ice-carnivals, because anything is good enough for
is good enough for them. You can play the shovel-game or crawl through barrels among the

ntertainment is not exceedingly amusing; I only mean that the artist in rink-making paints

The technique of these ice-pictures is in brief as follows:

bably more coherent in texture and less liable to contain holes through which the water may

of anything in this shifting world, everybody sits down and smokes (as is the habit of the

the unemployed leg is put out behind, the skater must lean forward in order to counteract
order to counteract its weight. He will then tend to skate on the forepart of his skate. In
rt of his skate. In a series of long edges this attitude is impossible to maintain except by

maintain except by effort. Nobody could skate for a quarter of an hour in combined skating,
accurately and largely on such a principle.

IV. The arms must hang by the side, and be carried loosely
easily, close to the body. Again the explanation is obvious. There
n is obvious. There is no need for their flying abroad, since a long edge is most easily
edge is most easily accomplished with the limbs and body in rest after the stroke, and these
e stroke, and these long smooth edges are part and parcel of English skating: it is founded
ting: it is founded on them. English skating postulates so perfect a balance, travelling on
ance, travelling on the middle of the skates, that it chooses (this is the reason for the
the reason for the rule) not to let that balance be assisted by the added or subtracted
added or subtracted weight of a correcting arm. It says (this is what it comes to) that you
comes to) that you must be so firm on your travelling root, so to speak, of balance, that

k, of balance, that you dispense with all adjustments of weight. The weight has to be
practically perfectly adjusted. There must be no adjustments
t be no adjustments adventitiously obtained.

Now these four rules are at the base of English skating. If you
happen to play a game, you conform to the rules, and you do not argue,
d you do not argue, for instance, when you are playing cricket, whether you should be given
you should be given out, when quite clearly you have been caught at the wicket. If you are
wicket. If you are at all sensible, or in any way like cricket, you pocket your duck’s egg

ket your duck’s egg and retire. Superb strokes may be made at cricket, which nevertheless
are fatal to the striker.
tal to the striker. Superb attitudes, similarly, may be made in the International style,
nternational style, which are quite completely wrong. They may be supremely statuesque, but
ely statuesque, but they are not skating. The case is exactly the same with the English
me with the English style. Certain canons have been laid down, all of which seem to be
of which seem to be necessary to the attainment of excellence. It is no doubt possible to
o doubt possible to skate charming “threes to a centre” doing everything quite wrong from
ng quite wrong from beginning to end. But if you choose to adopt a style, you must conform
e, you must conform to the rules of that style. Similarly, it is quite possible to skate the
ssible to skate the same “threes to a centre” in the International style, which shall leave
, which shall leave the same mark on the ice (though the skating of them broke every
of them broke every possible rule) as the most finished performer could leave there. But who
eave there. But who would not applaud the International judge who ruthlessly ploughed such a
sly ploughed such a candidate? He has not kept the rules, which in contradistinction to
ontradistinction to other games prescribe not only what the object in view is, but the
in view is, but the manner in which the performance is to take place. But this manner, we
But this manner, we venture to point out, has not been laid down in an arbitrary way: it is

rbitrary way: it is the manner, both in International skating and in English alike, in which
the feats demanded can alone be properly performed.

Now if the skater will take the trouble to conform to the four rules
given above, he will find that even at the outset of his career there is
his career there is great fun in store for him. Should he conform to them completely, when
em completely, when the complication of turns is added, he will quite certainly find that
certainly find that there is a championship, if he cares for that, in store for him also.
store for him also. The rules were not negligently made; indeed they were never made at all,

never made at all, but are simply the condensed experience of the best skaters, the methods
by which the

ethods
by which the fittest survived. And the fittest did, and always will do, that which is
l do, that which is recorded in these rules, and the ensuing complications, even the most
ions, even the most complicated of them, are comparatively easy to those who can maintain
se who can maintain the proper travelling position. But nobody who cannot hold a long firm
ot hold a long firm edge, for which the proper travelling position is essential, need ever
ssential, need ever trouble his dreams with the notion of becoming a good skater. And no
good skater. And no one’s edges approach perfection, if he cannot traverse, on backward and
se, on backward and forward edges, outside and inside alike, a distance of at least a
tance of at least a hundred yards, given that the ice is reasonably good, without stirring
d, without stirring from the attitude he has taken up after his stroke. A really fine skater
really fine skater will traverse much more, and be still as a rock throughout his travel;
oughout his travel; but no good skater will be so unsteady that he will not easily traverse
not easily traverse that. In his actual skating he will, probably, never be called upon to
r be called upon to make so lengthy an edge, but its accomplishment should present no
t should present no difficulty to him, if he aspires to be a fair performer. Even as the
former. Even as the pianist, when performing, is not called upon to play simple scales with
simple scales with both hands, so the skater will not be called upon, in his combined
on, in his combined figure, to skate for a hundred yards on one edge. But both pianist and

ut both pianist and skater ought to find no difficulty at all in executing these simple
feats.

The beginner is advised to get a fair mastery of all the edges before
he begins to attack the fortress of the turns. He should be able to
e should be able to progress steadily and smoothly both on the outside edge and the inside
edge and the inside edge forward, and to make some progress also on the back edges, namely,
back edges, namely, outside back and inside back. This last is far the most difficult of the

st difficult of the edges, and it will be a long time before he is able to take fast bold
strokes on it. But he should have
But he should have some acquaintance with it before he attempts to make the turns that
make the turns that necessitate its employment, and be able to hold it in the correct

d it in the correct position. He can then set about turns and changes of edge, which all
imply correct travelling.

Now there are four groups of turns, common both to the English and
International styles, each group of which contains four turns to be
ns four turns to be executed on each foot. Altogether, therefore, there are sixteen turns to
re sixteen turns to be learned which employ each foot singly. These with the four edges,

ith the four edges, executed in the prescribed manner, form the material of the art. These
turns are common both to English and International skating,

I. The first group is known as simple turns, and consists of turns
(or changes of direction, from backwards to forwards or forwards to
ards or forwards to backwards) from:

metadata.text_as_html:
(i)Outside forward to inside back.
(ii)Inside forward to outside back.
(iii)

text:
They are all of the same shape with regard to the marks they leave on
the ice, and from their shape are known as “three” turns, or
“threes.”

Thus:

[Image
unavailable.]

The arrow shows the direction of progress: the turn is the cusp in
the middle between the two curves. Thus if the first edge is outside

rst edge is outside forward, the second is inside back: if the first is inside forward the
second is outside back: if the first is outside back the

is outside back the second is inside forward: if the first is inside back the second is
outside forward.

II. The second group of turns is known as rocking turns, or more
generally as “rockers.” Like the “three” turns, they are all of the same
shape, thus:

[Image
unavailable.]

and are four in number, namely:

metadata.text_as_html:
(i)Outside forward to outside back.
(ii)Inside forward to inside back.
(iii)

text: (i) Outside forward to outside back. (ii) Inside forward to inside back. (iii) Outside back to outside forward. (iv) Inside back to inside forward.

metadata.text_as_html: d>Outside back to outside forward.(iv)Inside back to inside forward.

text:
Now, in both these groups the body revolves or rotates at the moment
of making the turn in the direction indicated by the dotted lines; it

he dotted lines; it revolves, that is to say, outside the direction of the first
curve. But it is possible for the body to revolve in the opposite

lve in the opposite direction, that is to say, inside the direction of its first
curve. This makes possible the third and fourth groups of turns.

III. This group, which is known as brackets, from the mark left on
the ice, corresponds to Group I, and the edges employed in it are the

loyed in it are the same, namely, outside forward to inside back, &c. But in this group
the body revolves on the inside of the direction of the first

ection of the first curve, and the mark on the ice, consequently, is as follows, the dotted
line again indicating the revolution of the body:

[Image
unavailable.]

IV. The fourth group is known as counter-rocking turns, or more
generally as counters. It corresponds with Group II, for the marks on
I, for the marks on the ice are approximately the same, and the edges employed are outside
mployed are outside forward to outside back, &c. But here again the revolution of the

e revolution of the body, as in the brackets, takes inside the direction of the first curve,
thus:

[Image
unavailable.]

These sixteen turns, or changes of direction while skating on one
foot, comprise all the varieties of so doing that seem theoretically
seem theoretically possible, since they include every forward edge to every back edge and
every back edge and every back edge to every forward edge, skated with rotation of the body
otation of the body both outside and inside the direction of the first curve, and until
st curve, and until somebody discovers a third edge to a skate, or a third direction of
third direction of rotating the body, it is not possible that they will be added to.

But changes of direction may be made by the employment, not of one
but of both feet, and though these might be more properly described as

operly described as strokes rather than turns, there are two groups of them which enter
largely into English skating. These are known as mohawks and
nown as mohawks and choctaws.

I. Mohawks consist of either forward edge combined with the
corresponding back edge taken up by the other foot. Thus if the right

. Thus if the right foot starts as an outside forward, the left, to complete the mohawk, is
put down on the outside back edge, thus:

[Image
unavailable.]

Here the rotation is made, as in the brackets and counters, on the
inside of the direction of the first curve, and the figure is
, and the figure is known as the outside forward mohawk. Similarly, the mohawk can be skated
ohawk can be skated on the inside edges, i.e. the right foot starts with an inside
arts with an inside forward, and the left completes with an inside back. Here the rotation,

Here the rotation, as in the threes and rockers, takes place on the outside of the
direction of the first curve.

II. Choctaws also employ both feet, but the second curve of a choctaw
is on the opposing edge to the first curve. An outside forward choctaw

ide forward choctaw thus consists of an outside forward on one foot completed by an inside
back on the other, thus:

[Image
unavailable.]

In this, as in the corresponding mohawk, and the brackets and
counters, the rotation of the body takes place inside the
es place inside the direction of the first curve. Similarly, the inside forward choctaw
ide forward choctaw consists of an inside forward on one foot and an outside back on the

outside back on the other. Here, following the corresponding mohawk, the rotation of the
body takes place outside the first curve.

Theoretically, of course, there are corresponding mohawks and
choctaws starting from the back edges, i.e. outside back to
.e. outside back to outside forward, &c., but though these strokes are constantly used,
re constantly used, both in single and combined skating, they are never dignified by this
r dignified by this sounding title of “back mohawk” or “back choctaw,” merely because the
merely because the manœuvre is so simple and common a one, that it needs no name at all,

eds no name at all, and if, for instance, in combined skating, the caller (who directs what
shall be done) has his skaters on a back

s skaters on a back edge, and desires that the next stroke, let us say, shall be an inside
forward edge, he calls “inside forward” merely.

Finally, in giving this catalogue of material out of which all
English skating is built, there remain only the changes of edge, made on

es of edge, made on one foot, to enumerate. They, as must naturally be the case, are four in
number:

metadata.text_as_html:
(i)Outside forward to inside forward.
(ii)Inside forward to outside forward.
(iii)<

text:
With regard to the cross-mohawks and cross-choctaws—in case the
skater ever “hears tell” of them—he need not worry himself even to
rry himself even to remember their existence, since, most rightly, they have been blotted
y have been blotted out of the book of English skating, owing to their clumsiness and the
clumsiness and the fact that to skate any of them violates some canon of the essential form
the essential form of English skating. Apart from them, the whole material of English
material of English skating has now been stated, namely, the four edges, the sixteen turns,
the sixteen turns, the two mohawks, the two choctaws, and the four changes of edge.

But when we consider that the first-class skater must be able to
skate at high speed on any edge, make any turn at a fixed point, and
a fixed point, and leave that fixed point (having made his turn and edge in compliance with
in compliance with the proper form for English skating, without scrape or wavering) still
or wavering) still on a firm and large-circumferenced curve, that he must be able to
he must be able to combine any mohawk and choctaw with any of the sixteen turns, and any of
n turns, and any of the sixteen turns with any change of edge, and that in combined skating

in combined skating he is frequently called upon to do all these permutations of edge and
turn, at a fixed point, and in
fixed point, and in time with his partner, while two other partners are performing the same
performing the same evolution in time with each other, it begins to become obvious that
become obvious that there is considerable variety to be obtained out of these manœuvres. But
hese manœuvres. But the consideration of combined skating, which is the cream and
ch is the cream and quintessence of English skating, must be considered last; at present we

last; at present we will see what the single skater may be called upon to do, if he wishes
to attain to acknowledged excellence in his sport.

Now the National Skating Association of Great Britain encourages both
the English and International styles, and for each there have been
ach there have been instituted certain graduated tests, not competitive but standard, of
ve but standard, of three orders. The third or lowest test in the English style is broadly

sh style is broadly designed to encourage skaters, the second to discourage them again
(i.e. begin to make them feel the difficulty of the whole
iculty of the whole affair, just when they thought by passing their third test they had
third test they had broken the back of their difficulties), and the first or highest to give
or highest to give them healthy occupation for a few winters, and fit them for becoming
t them for becoming really first-class skaters. All of these tests must be passed before at

be passed before at least two qualified judges, appointed by the N.S.A., and they are as
follows:—

THIRD-CLASS
TEST

(a) A forward outside three on each foot, the length of each
curve being 15 feet at least. The figure need not be skated to a
centre.

(b) The four edges, outside forward, inside forward, outside
back, inside back, on each foot alternately for as long as the judges

long as the judges shall require, the length of each curve being 15
feet at least on the forward edges and 10 feet at on the back edges.

(c) A forward outside 8, the diameter of each circle being 8
feet at least, to be skated three times without pause.

Here, it will be seen, is the beginning, the ground-work of English
skating. The easiest turn has to be skated, the four edges have to be
ur edges have to be skated; also the easiest “8” has to be skated, in order to familiarise
rder to familiarise the beginner with the idea of leaving a point on one stroke and
t on one stroke and continuing to travel on that stroke (with turns to punctuate it, as he
punctuate it, as he will see later) until he arrives back at that point again. The point in
again. The point in question is marked for him on the ice with an orange or a ball. And
ange or a ball. And whether in single skating or in combined, it is called the centre.
called the centre. Simple as this third test is, it has to be skated in proper English
d in proper English form, which the learner should begin to acquire from the first moment he
the first moment he takes a serious stroke on the ice. For it is vastly easier to acquire

y easier to acquire good form at the beginning of his education, than to acquire bad habits
which must subsequently be got rid of.

SECOND-CLASS
TEST

(a) A set of combined figures skated with another skater,
who will be selected by the judges, introducing the following calls in
following calls in such order and with such repetitions as the judges may direct:—

(b) The judges shall call three “unseen” figures of quite
simple character, in order to test the candidate’s knowledge of calls

knowledge of calls and power of placing figures upon the ice. These shall be skated
alone.

(c) The following edges on each foot alternately for as long
as the judges shall require, namely:—

feet without pause, three times on each foot, namely:—

text:
Here, it will be seen, the test begins with a combined figure. The
whole subject of combined figures will be treated of separately, and
of separately, and for the present we need only remark that this is a very simple one. Then
ry simple one. Then follow the inside back edge, which, as I have said, is the most
e said, is the most difficult of the edges, skated larger than before, in curves of 20 feet,
curves of 20 feet, and the cross-stroke on the outside back. This means that the stroke is
that the stroke is taken with the feet crossing, the one that is taking the stroke being
ng the stroke being crossed behind the other. As a matter of fact, this stroke, which at one
troke, which at one time played a considerable part in English skating, since in combined
, since in combined figures all strokes from outside back to outside back were bound to be
ck were bound to be taken from the crossing position, is now not obligatory. But it is a
gatory. But it is a pretty stroke in itself, and necessitates the skate being placed on the
being placed on the ice on the edge. Then follow the two forward turns, skated rather large,
kated rather large, in order to begin to familiarise the learner with the feeling of turns
he feeling of turns taken at a high speed. This necessitates clean skating of the turn
skating of the turn itself, since if a turn is skated fast, and not clean, it is quite
clean, it is quite possible that the skater may fall, and he will in any case make a blur
ny case make a blur instead of a sharp cut turn. Also these turns teach him to hold his
ach him to hold his edges out after the turn, the tendency being to let the body rotate,
et the body rotate, whereby the curve curls in, and the skater soon finds himself in a
finds himself in a position that it is impossible to maintain. But if he skates his turn,
he skates his turn, and then can hold an edge for 50 feet away from it afterwards,
from it afterwards, he may congratulate himself on the fact that he is beginning to skate
beginning to skate his edges big and in the proper style. For these cannot, practically
cannot, practically speaking, be held out, unless the rules for position are being conformed
are being conformed with. Then follow four simple figures of the class known as 8’s, of
ss known as 8’s, of which the simplest is that required in the third-class test, namely, an

ss test, namely, an outside forward 8. All 8’s, as their name denotes, are of the same
general shape, i.e. the shape implied by
he shape implied by their name, but between the edges that trace the shape of the 8, the
shape of the 8, the skater is now required to put in certain turns. He starts, for instance,
arts, for instance, on an outside forward edge, when half round his circle makes a three
ircle makes a three turn, and comes back to his centre on the inside back edge. Or he starts
edge. Or he starts on an inside forward edge as in the third 8, and has to make two turns
s to make two turns before he arrives at his centre again, which he reaches as an inside
eaches as an inside forward edge. Or, more searchingly, he has to start his 8 on an outside

his 8 on an outside back edge, and make two turns and aim at his centre again on an outside
back edge.

The remainder of this test is taken up with the figures known as Q’s.
In these the skater is required to start, at some speed, on any edge
speed, on any edge forward or back, and after travelling on it for varying distances, as
rying distances, as laid down, to change his edge (from outside to inside, or inside to
nside, or inside to outside) and after holding that edge for the prescribed distance make
ribed distance make the three appropriate to that edge. The Q’s are very largely used in
ery largely used in combined skating, the change of edge being coupled not only to “three”
not only to “three” turns, but to rockers, counters and brackets. Here the name “Q” is
ere the name “Q” is becoming obsolete, and indeed has become so in combined skating, the

mbined skating, the figure being called “forward change three” or “inside back change
three,” &c.

Now, as I have said, while the third test is supposed to encourage
the skater, the second is supposed to discourage him. What is meant is
m. What is meant is that he has now run up against the really crucial difficulties in
ial difficulties in English skating, of which perhaps the greatest of all is to stand still,
is to stand still, as the Irishman might say, while moving rapidly. As will be already seen

ill be already seen in this test, he is required to do this for somewhat extensive travel:
in his outside forward turn, for
e forward turn, for instance, he has to proceed for at least fifty feet on his forward edge
on his forward edge before making his turn, and the same distance on his back edge after
his back edge after making his turn. And though this present disquisition is intended to be
n is intended to be a statement of English skating and not a book of instruction, the writer
ruction, the writer cannot bear to let this one opportunity slip of giving just one hint. It
g just one hint. It is perfectly impossible to travel steadily for distances like these—and
nces like these—and the skater will have to learn to go much further yet on his edges—if he
on his edges—if he is travelling on the forepart of his skate. All forward turns, by the
rward turns, by the slight check they give to the speed (I am not now talking of those ideal
king of those ideal skaters who actually get speed out of a turn), tend to put the skater
d to put the skater further forward on his skate. He must therefore approach all forward
pproach all forward turns on the back part of his skate, so that by this tendency to rock
is tendency to rock forward he will make the turn itself on about the middle of the skate.
iddle of the skate. Never for a moment, if he can help it, must he get on the toe of his
t on the toe of his skate, and if ever he does, he must regain position again by leaning
on again by leaning fearlessly back. And in this second test, he will find that the
will find that the difficulty of travelling well back on his skate is at first appalling.
at first appalling. But having learned that, and learned it thoroughly, he will probably not

e will probably not come across any subsequent requirement which appears to him so clearly
impossible.

FIRST-CLASS
TEST

Section A

This section consists of the combined figures in Parts I and II. The
judges may also give such simple calls as they think fit, to enable the
fit, to enable the candidate to recover his position, to alternate the feet, &c.

The figures shall be skated with another skater, to be selected by
the judges, but if there are only two judges, neither of them shall
skate.

Each call must be skated at least twice, beginning once with the
right foot and once with the left.

Subject to these conditions the calls shall be skated in such order
and with such repetitions as the judges may, while the set is in
progress, direct.

In calls introducing “twice back” the candidate must recede at least
35 feet from the centre.

To pass this section the candidate must satisfy all the judges in the
manner in which he skates each set considered as a whole, and also in
whole, and also in the manner in which he skates each individual call.

The judges may pass a candidate in Part I, notwithstanding a
reasonable number of errors on his part in the course of the set,
course of the set, provided that he ultimately skates all the calls to their satisfaction;

their satisfaction; and in Part II, notwithstanding errors, provided that the candidate has
shown competent skill in skating unseen calls.

Part I

1. Twice back—and forward three—and forward inside three, off
meet.

2. Twice back—and forward three threes—and back meet—and back two
threes—and forward two threes, meet.

3. Twice back—and forward three about, change, meet.

4. Twice back, about—and back off meet.

5. Twice back—and back inside centre three, change—and forward
meet.

6. Twice back three, centre three, off meet.

7. Twice back centre change, three, meet.

8. Once back—and forward—and forward inside two threes centre change
meet.

9. Twice back—and forward two threes, pass, meet.

10. Twice back two threes, off pass, meet.
11. Inside twice back—and forward inside two threes, meet.

12. Forward change, three, change, three, circle—and forward three,
change, circle—and forward about change, three, off meet.

Part II

In addition to the above, the judges shall call a further set of not
more than six or less than four “unseen” figures of moderate difficulty,
oderate difficulty, in order to test the candidate’s knowledge of calls and power of correct

nd power of correct placing. This unseen set must include rockers, counters, and brackets,
and shall be skated by the candidate alone.

Section B

No candidate shall be judged in Part II of this Section until he has
passed in Part I.

The judges may allow a candidate any number of attempts at a given
figure which they consider reasonable.

Part I

The turns, mohawks, and choctaws of this part must be placed close to
and on the near side of an orange or other fixed point on the ice. They
nt on the ice. They must all be skated on each foot to the satisfaction of the judges.

The curve before and after the turn or change of foot must be 40 feet
long at least.

text: Part II

To pass in this part, a candidate may select not more than one figure
in each group, and must score forty-five marks at least. A selection
least. A selection once made by a candidate must not be altered.

No marks shall be scored in respect of any one-footed figure unless
it is skated on each foot, and the number set against each figure
against each figure represents the maximum that can be scored for that figure.

A candidate shall not score for any figure on which he shall not have
obtained at least half marks.

Eights.—In marking these figures, the judges will take into
consideration the general symmetry of the figure, and the approximate
and the approximate equality of corresponding curves.

In each figure the complete 8 is to be skated three times without
pause.

The figures need not be commenced from rest.

In groups D and E the turns and choctaws respectively are to be made
on the near side of the centre.

The following eights are to be skated to a centre on alternate
feet:—

text:
Now, again omitting for the moment the subject of combined skating,
we see that in Part II the rest of the groundwork of English skating is
English skating is very thoroughly traversed. To pass this final test the skater has to be
he skater has to be able to execute all the threes (the two simple ones are omitted, as they
re omitted, as they have already been required in the second test), rockers, brackets,
rockers, brackets, counters, mohawks, and choctaws at fair speed and on large edges at a
on large edges at a given point on the ice. Having done that to the satisfaction of the
satisfaction of the judges, he has then to make his selection from a large number of 8’s,
arge number of 8’s, which include practically most possible 8’s comprising one or two turns,
g one or two turns, excepting these simple ones with regard to which he has already
hich he has already satisfied the judges in his second test. Here he has to score marks,
has to score marks, selecting not more than one 8 of each group, and by the devilish
and by the devilish ingenuity of those who drew up this test, it is impossible for him to
possible for him to get through unless the majority of the 8’s he selects to skate are
elects to skate are really difficult. He may then add to his marks by executing what are
executing what are called reverse Q’s at two given points on the ice. At the first of these
the first of these he has to make his turn, whatever it is, and at the second to change his
econd to change his edge. This requires a considerable degree of accuracy, for in order to
cy, for in order to arrive smoothly and still at a fair travelling pace at the second point,
t the second point, he will find that he has to have a practically perfect control of the
fect control of the edge, which has not been disturbed by executing a difficult back turn,
ifficult back turn, let us say, at the first given point. Finally, if he is still in want of
is still in want of marks, he may earn a few more by a grape-vine. This latter does not
his latter does not properly belong to English skating, since it is a two-footed figure, and

-footed figure, and those responsible for the test might have omitted this group with
advantage.

The Combined Figure.—Probably no branch of sport—except,
perhaps, flying—has undergone such improvement and revolution within the
volution within the last fifteen years as this art of combined skating. Not only are there a
ot only are there a vastly multiplied number of competent and even first-rate combined
first-rate combined skaters, but the skill demanded of a first-rate combined skater, and the
ned skater, and the variety of the manœuvres he may be called upon to execute, is
upon to execute, is immeasurably greater than a decade and a half ago. I do not mean that
I do not mean that there were not in 1897 a certain number of skaters who might have been
who might have been able to execute a difficult set as directed by a caller of to-day, but

ller of to-day, but these were, in golfing parlance, “plus players,” and the ordinary
“scratch” skater—one, that is, who had passed his First Class
sed his First Class N.S.A.—would have had no more chance of getting through such a set
through such a set without throwing everybody out, and himself down, than he would have of
an he would have of flying. Both the speed and the size of these combined figures has
ombined figures has greatly increased, and the whole of the material of English skating is
English skating is employed. And the main reason for this improvement and revolution is due
d revolution is due to the greatly augmented number of English skaters who now go to

aters who now go to Switzerland in the winter, and the multiplication there of really large
rinks.

That this immense improvement has taken place in combined skating is
proved, luckily, not only by the fallacious memory of individuals, but
of individuals, but by printed records. I have before me the Badminton volume on skating

n volume on skating (edition 1902), in which, for instance, we find the following figure
(among many others like it).

“Forward two turns. This movement skated to a centre is very
difficult, and is a great test of good skating, and many men make a
and many men make a practice of devoting five or ten minutes to skating it every day
kating it every day when they come on the ice, feeling that if they can skate it, making the
kate it, making the curves between the turns of equal length and making the turns clean
ing the turns clean without any scrape and yet coming true to the centre, they are in good
e, they are in good form and equal to skate anything that may be required of them.”

Now no doubt two turns to a centre, as required in the second-class
test, is a very good elementary figure, but it no longer has anything
longer has anything whatever to do with combined skating, whether it is skated with a
it is skated with a partner or with a second pair, or simultaneously with other skaters.
with other skaters. Speed and size and difficulty (as demanded by the scale on which
the scale on which combined skaters now move) are necessarily absent from it, and from a
from it, and from a hundred others of these calls which then were the last word in combined
st word in combined skating. A man who had passed his second-class test would be capable of
would be capable of doing this, which was then considered a criterion of good combined
on of good combined skating, whereas the same man could not live for two calls in a combined
calls in a combined figure of moderate difficulty to-day. The whole nature of the business
ure of the business has changed: turns have to be executed at high speed far away from the
d far away from the centre, and the curliness and smallness of such skating as is here

skating as is here implied and necessitated has vanished altogether, giving place to a far
more difficult style and speed.

Nor, again, in this respect, is Part I, in the first-class English
test, up-to-date in requirements of size. Here we read that on a “twice
ad that on a “twice back” the candidate must recede at least 35 feet from the centre. That
om the centre. That no doubt was laid down because on the artificial rinks available in
rinks available in England, such a distance took the skaters nearly to the bounds of the

o the bounds of the space at his disposal. But any candidate who, on the Swiss rinks, where
nowadays almost all first-class tests are passed,
s tests are passed, receded but 35 feet from the centre would have, practically speaking, no
ically speaking, no chance of getting through. His lawless judges would inevitably tell him
inevitably tell him to skate larger. Still less would he be able to take part in any
to take part in any combined figure-skating for amusement by skaters who had any pretension
had any pretension to be of the first-class. With these big surfaces of rink, the whole

of rink, the whole style and method has become larger and faster, and therefore more
difficult.

A third instance, to prove how greatly the art of combined skating
has progressed, has the ring of pathos about it, and, though only oral,
, though only oral, is trustworthy. A friend of mine, who resides at that excellent English
t excellent English skating centre, Oxford, told me that in old days he could scarcely get a
ould scarcely get a combined figure, since the most elementary calls were sufficient to
were sufficient to floor his partners. But not so long ago he told me he could scarcely get
could scarcely get a combined figure, since nobody cared to skate such elementary calls as
elementary calls as he was capable of. But he assures me that he skates just as well now as
just as well now as he did in the days when there was nobody up to his standard. Perhaps in
tandard. Perhaps in twenty years more, no first-class skater will care to engage in such
e to engage in such simple stuff as we now think rather advanced. And dearly will such
nd dearly will such present-day skaters who are fortunate enough to be alive then, love to
alive then, love to see the newer and more arduous manœuvres! But since it is impossible to
it is impossible to prophesy about the things we cannot imagine, it must be sufficient to

st be sufficient to give the outlines of combined skating as practised by fairly expert
gentlemen to-day.

There are two manners of combined skating, called respectively
pair-skating and simultaneous skating. The first of these (which we will

hese (which we will first consider) is the more difficult, and, so to speak, the more
classical. Theoretically it can be skated by two, four, six, or
two, four, six, or eight persons: practically it is skated by four persons, grouped, at the
ns, grouped, at the beginning of things, at right angles to their neighbours, and at a few
bours, and at a few yards distant from their centre. One of these, who skates in the first
skates in the first pair, is known as the caller, and he announces (in a loud mellifluous
a loud mellifluous voice) what he is about to skate, and what the trembling gentleman
trembling gentleman opposite, who is his partner, must also skate. They advance to the
They advance to the centre, from opposite sides, and begin skating whatever is ordered. The

ver is ordered. The moment after they have left their centre, speeding out to the
circumference of the huge imaginary circle, of which their orange or
ich their orange or india-rubber ball, from which they have started, is the centre, the
is the centre, the second pair (at right angles to them) proceed to do exactly the same.
o exactly the same. The size and pace of the figure, as well as its details, depend entirely
ls, depend entirely on the caller: as he skates, so must his partner skate, putting down his
e, putting down his edges and turns simultaneously and at like speed to him, and as the

to him, and as the first pair skate, so (with certain modifications) must the second pair
skate.

Now, the whole material of skating is at the caller’s command. He can
(and does) order threes, brackets, rockers, counters, mohawks, choctaws
, mohawks, choctaws and changes of edge to be skated when and how he wishes them. He can
wishes them. He can (and does) couple any pair or any three of these movements, to be skated
ments, to be skated on one foot or on both, one after the other. He directs, with a word of
cts, with a word of power, from the elaborate vocabulary of combined skating, the length of
ting, the length of an edge, and can command it to be held so long that the direction of
at the direction of progress is reversed, or to be further continued till a complete circle

l a complete circle is made and the original direction of progress resumed again. Then, with
another word, he brings himself and his partner (followed
s partner (followed closely by the second pair) back to their centre again, on the off side
in, on the off side or the near side of it, and orders that they shall start a fresh figure
tart a fresh figure there, or that they shall make a turn there, or scud by it like four
cud by it like four express trains which just, and only just, arriving from the four parts
from the four parts of the compass, do not collide with each other, and scatter again to
nd scatter again to east and west and north and south. Sometimes he brings them in
s he brings them in simultaneously, so that they converge till they almost touch, and then
ost touch, and then spread out again. And if the figure is going decently well, there is no
y well, there is no pause, no foot without its edge and turn assigned to it. This mystic,

to it. This mystic, swift, interweaving dance lasts perhaps a quarter of an hour of hard,
enraptured skating.

Simultaneous combined has this advantage, that an uneven number of
skaters can take part in it. The caller’s duties are the same, but there
the same, but there are no pairs of partners. All leave the centre simultaneously, all (it
ltaneously, all (it is hoped) arrive back at it simultaneously. Since there is no crossing
here is no crossing of pairs at the centre, a far larger number of skaters can take part in
rs can take part in it, as they have not to wait for a prior pair to clear, and if
ir to clear, and if elementary calls only are ordered, upwards of ten or twelve skaters can
twelve skaters can join the dance with effect. No one of them, as in pair skating, crosses
ir skating, crosses the path of another skater: they leave and arrive at the centre on
ve at the centre on converging not crossing lines. Thus it is an easier sport than is
asier sport than is crossing pairs, since in the latter case the edges that leave and
dges that leave and approach the centre intersect each other. Vastly enjoyable as it is, it

oyable as it is, it lacks to the present writer that classical distinction that
characterises pair-skating.

The final item in English skating is hand-in-hand skating in the
combined figure. Here, instead of single skaters combining to
katers combining to perform in unison, pairs take the place of units. Necessarily the
ts. Necessarily the figures compassable by a man and woman hand in hand are fewer in number,
re fewer in number, as at present worked out, than those which can be skated by single
be skated by single skaters, and the speed at which such figures are skated is less than in
ted is less than in the combined skating of single skaters. Hand-holds have to be changed,

have to be changed, and partners brought into the new position required by turns, &c.,
by pulls, or by what in the nomenclature is called “steps”—i.e.
called “steps”—i.e. single strokes and edges. Already this style has taken the place in the
en the place in the annual championship of English skating, and without doubt it will grow
doubt it will grow both in the number of its practitioners, and in the force and speed of
force and speed of their movements. It is scientifically based, being evolved from the
ng evolved from the charming movements that are possible to hand-in-hand skaters when going
skaters when going free on the ice, and not bound to consider their opposing partner, or to
sing partner, or to arrive in a given manner at a given point. But it resembles, at present,
embles, at present, in the opinion of the writer, the performance of a yearling. It requires
arling. It requires the devotion of a dozen first-class skaters of both sexes to determine
sexes to determine its possibilities. His wish is, that it will get them. His fear is that
m. His fear is that the necessarily cramping influence of conjoined hands will prove to

hands will prove to debar it from the speed and largeness of other branches of English
skating. He sincerely hopes that his fears are quite unfounded.
International Style

It has been already remarked that the two styles, English and
International, have nothing to do with each other, and that the
other, and that the practitioner of one who is so imbecile as to belittle the other, is no
le the other, is no less crack-brained and idiotic than a Rugby football player who calls
ll player who calls Association a “rotten game.” Personally, I do not skate in the
do not skate in the International style, but to attempt to depreciate the beauties of it
the beauties of it would be to me as unthinkable as it would be to run down polo. To the
n down polo. To the spectator, whether of polo or of International skating, the skill and
ting, the skill and the splendour of these sports are, unless he is entirely lunatic, beyond
ely lunatic, beyond any question at all. But it is as an admirer, pure and simple, that I

and simple, that I venture to embark on a subject with which I have no practical
acquaintance.

Spectacularly there is no doubt that to the ignorant the
International style rightly makes the most powerful appeal. A simple
ul appeal. A simple manœuvre, as for instance a forward three to a centre, looks far more
tre, looks far more difficult and hazardous when executed even only moderately well in the
erately well in the International style than when executed almost perfectly in the English
ctly in the English style. In the one case, to the ignorant, arms and legs are flying: it
legs are flying: it seems impossible to maintain a balance, and the attitude itself is
attitude itself is charmingly graceful: whereas in the English style the whole difficulty

he whole difficulty of the manœuvre, such as it is, lies in the necessity of making it look
easy, and standing quite still and at rest.

But the difficulty of doing it perfectly in the English style is, as
a matter of fact, far greater than that of doing it properly in the
it properly in the International style. Of that there is no question whatever. A good
on whatever. A good English skater will put down his turns and edges one over the other, in
over the other, in the accurate fashion so rightly demanded by the International style,
nternational style, without producing half the effect that a good International skater will

ational skater will produce. But the English skater has done the more difficult feat. On the
other hand, I do not think that
I do not think that the skater in the English style is ever called upon to do anything so
n to do anything so difficult in his highest test as the back-loop 8, or perhaps the rocker
perhaps the rocker 8, as required by the first-class International test. And then I think
t. And then I think of a back bracket, executed at good speed at a certain point, in the
rtain point, in the correct style. Really I do not know.... Also I do not care. The

I do not care. The back-loop 8 of the International skater is altogether lovely, which is
all that matters.

But, as I have said, the two styles have nothing to do with each
other, either as regards tests or as regards the general sport of them.
eral sport of them. I can imagine no more glorious athletic feat than that of four
t than that of four first-class English skaters performing a really difficult combined set
ficult combined set properly, a set that is as far away from the compulsory set of the
mpulsory set of the first-class test as is the first-class test from the second; nor, on the
second; nor, on the other hand, can I imagine a more glorious athletic feat than the free
feat than the free skating of some champion of the International school. But when Mr.
chool. But when Mr. Grenander or Herr Salchow are so kind as to show me the Hugel star, I no
he Hugel star, I no more think of comparing that with the combined skating of fine
ned skating of fine performers in the English style, and others, than I compare it with Mr.

compare it with Mr. Baerlein in the tennis court or Mr. Jessop slogging his sixes. They have
nothing to do with each other.

As in English skating, I propose to lay before the reader the tests
of the International school, and in contrast to the rule of English
the rule of English form, I subpend the essential requirements of International excellence,
ational excellence, as laid down by the collective experience of its senators. Proper form

nators. Proper form is no less essential in one than in the other, and the same sternness of
requirement is insisted on in both. But the
on in both. But the effect is poles apart: in the International style a fixed freedom of the

ixed freedom of the unemployed limbs is necessary, in the English a fixed quietness and
immobility. Neither is laid down in an arbitrary manner: it is
trary manner: it is impossible to perform the necessary evolutions in first-class skating
first-class skating otherwise than is provided by the rules. No English skater could, in his
kater could, in his prescribed form, execute the International figures: no International
s: no International skater in his could do what is required of his English brother. Here,

lish brother. Here, then, are the essentials of good form as demanded by the International
school:

“Carriage upright but not stiff; the body not bent forwards or
sideways at the waist; all raising or lowering of the body being
g of the body being effected by bending the knee of the tracing leg with upright back; the
h upright back; the body and limbs generally held sideways to the direction of progress. The
on of progress. The head always upright. Tracing leg flexible with bent knee. The eyes
bent knee. The eyes looking downwards as little as possible. The knee and toe of the free
and toe of the free leg turned outwards as far as possible, the toe always downwards; the
ways downwards; the knee only slightly bent. The free leg swinging freely from the hip and
ly from the hip and assisting the movement. The arms held easily, and assisting the
, and assisting the movement; the hands neither spread nor clenched. All action of the body
action of the body and limbs must be easy and swinging with the direct object of assisting

object of assisting the movement of the moment; violent or stiff motions are to be avoided,
the figure should seem to be executed without difficulty.

“The figures must be begun from rest—that is, by a single stroke with
the other foot; and at the intersecting point of two circles. Every

two circles. Every figure must be repeated three times consecutively. No
impetus may be taken from the ice by the foot which is about to become

is about to become the tracing foot; and every stroke should be taken from the edge of the
blade, not from the point.”

There are also the following directions for correct tracing,
i.e. the marks left by the skate on the ice.

“The essentials of correct tracing are:

“Maintenance of the long and transverse axes (as the long axis of the
figure a line is to be conceived which divides each circle into two
ach circle into two equal parts; a transverse axis cuts the long axis at right angles
xis at right angles between two circles); approximately equal size of all circles, and of
all circles, and of all curves before and after all turns; symmetrical grouping of the
cal grouping of the individual parts of the figure about the axes; curves without wobbles,
es without wobbles, skated out—that is, returning nearly to the starting-point. Threes with

-point. Threes with the turns lying in the long axis; changes of edge with an easy
transition, the change falling in the long axis.”

In this form, then, and with this accuracy of tracing, the following
figures must be skated for the third test:—

text:
Into the system of marking—candidates have to get a certain
proportion of marks in each figure—we need not go. It will be sufficient

will be sufficient to say that it is necessary to skate each figure passably, and to earn
more than half marks on the whole.
Second-class Test

This has to be passed before three judges, and is divided into two
parts—(1) Compulsory Figures; (2) Free Skating. The regulations for them
egulations for them are as follow:—

(1) Compulsory Figures.—Each figure may be marked up to a
maximum of 6 points. The marks given for each figure are multiplied by
e are multiplied by the factor of value for that figure. In order to pass, a candidate must

s, a candidate must obtain a minimum of 2 marks out of 6 in each figure, and an aggregate of
130 out of the maximum of 234 marks.

(2) Free Skating.—The candidate will be required to skate a
free programme of three minutes’ duration.

This will be marked:

(a) For the contents of the programme (difficulty and
variety) up to a maximum of 6 marks.

(b) For the manner of performance up to a maximum of 6
marks. In order to pass, a candidate must obtain 7 marks for
(a) and (b) together.

The marks for compulsory figures and for free skating must be
obtained from each judge. Judges may use half marks and quarter
marks.

Compulsory
Figures
