text:
Here is a remarkably varied programme, and one that will obviously
give a good spell of regular work to a candidate who intends to grapple
intends to grapple with it. It contains more of the material for skating than does the
ating than does the corresponding English second test, in which only the four edges, the
the four edges, the four simple turns, and the four changes of edge are introduced, since

e introduced, since this International second test comprises as well as those, the four
loops, and two out of the four brackets. These
our brackets. These loops, which are most charming and effective figures, have nowadays no
s, have nowadays no place in English skating, since it is quite impossible to execute any of

e to execute any of them, as far as is at present known, without breaking the rules for
English skating, since the unemployed leg (i.e. the one not
g (i.e. the one not tracing the figure) must be used to get the necessary balance and swing.
balance and swing. They belong to a great class of figures like cross-cuts in all their
s-cuts in all their varieties, beaks, pigs-ears, &c., in which the skater nearly, or
e skater nearly, or actually, stops still for a moment, and then, by a swing of the body or
wing of the body or leg, resumes or reverses his movement. By this momentary loss and
momentary loss and recovery of balance there is opened out to the skater whole new fields
er whole new fields of intricate and delightful movements, and the patterns that can be
atterns that can be traced on the ice are of endless variety. And here in this second
here in this second International test the confines of this territory are entered on by the
e entered on by the four loops, which are the simplest of the “check and recovery” figures.
recovery” figures. In the loops (the shape of which is accurately expressed by their names)
sed by their names) the skater does not come absolutely to a standstill, though very nearly,
though very nearly, and the swing of the body and leg is then thrown forward in front of the
ard in front of the skate, and this restores to it its velocity, and pulls it, so to speak,
ls it, so to speak, out of its loop. A further extension of this check and resumption of
k and resumption of speed occurs in cross-cuts, which do not enter into the International
o the International tests, but which figure largely in the performance of good skaters. Here
good skaters. Here the forward movement of the skate (or backward movement, if back
d movement, if back cross-cuts are being skated) is entirely checked, the skater comes to a
e skater comes to a momentary standstill and moves backwards for a second. Then the forward

d. Then the forward swing of the body and unemployed leg gives him back his checked and
reversed movement.

Similarly, the bracket 8 is fresh material in this set of compulsory
figures. The shape and nature of the bracket is the same as that in
the same as that in English skating.

The candidate for the second International test has also to skate a
free programme of three minutes’ duration. This takes the place, so to
es the place, so to speak, of the section in the English test devoted to combined skating,

o combined skating, which is not practised in the International style. This free skating is
spoken of in its place under the first-class test.
First-class Test

This has to be passed before three judges, and is divided into two
parts—(1) Compulsory Figures; (2) Free Skating. The regulations for them
egulations for them are as follow:—

(1) Compulsory Figures.—Each figure may be marked up to a
maximum of 6 points. The marks given for each figure are multiplied by
e are multiplied by the factor of value for that figure. In order to pass, a candidate must

s, a candidate must obtain a minimum of 2 marks out of 6 in each figure, and an aggregate of
190 out of the maximum of 336 marks.

(2) Free Skating.—The candidate will be required to skate a
free programme of three minutes’ duration.

This will be marked:

(a) For the contents of the programme (difficulty and
variety) up to a maximum of 6 marks.

(b) For the manner of performance up to a maximum of 6
marks.

In order to pass, a candidate must obtain 7 marks for (a)
and (b) together.

The marks for the compulsory figures and the free skating are arrived
at by taking the total marks of the three judges and dividing by three.
dividing by three. Judges may use half marks.

This free skating is a charming item in the system of International
skating, and might, with great advantage, be introduced into the English
ed into the English branch. It is in itself perfectly fascinating to look at, and from the
ok at, and from the technical point of view it is quite admirable as a test of knowledge. A
est of knowledge. A good programme will contain dozens of turns and changes of edge, all
hanges of edge, all melting into each other without break or pause. None who have seen the
e who have seen the free skating of a fine performer can ever forget or question the
get or question the brilliance and variety of this three-minute free skating. As likely as
ating. As likely as not, he will make his entry on to the rink in a spiral edge, and before
al edge, and before it has come to rest at the centre, start off on his coruscating
on his coruscating performance. Rockers, brackets, counters, and turns succeed each other
succeed each other with bewildering rapidity; and all are performed with the utmost ease
ith the utmost ease and grace. It seems impossible to tell where the motive-power comes
motive-power comes from, so smooth and effortless is the travelling; you would have said
you would have said the skater was wafted by some localised wind, or impelled by some
or impelled by some invisible mechanism. But before he arrives at this part of his test, he
art of his test, he has to skate his compulsory figures, the list of which is subjoined.

Compulsory
Figures

text:
Now, here is a list of requirements which, when we think of the
accuracy demanded by the International style in the matter of tracing,
matter of tracing, will clearly be too much for any but the very elect. Not only has a
ect. Not only has a figure as difficult as the back-loop 8 to be skated, but it has to be
d, but it has to be skated with accuracy: the loops must lie approximately one on the top of

y one on the top of the other, and the edges that lead into and out of them must be
symmetrically laid down. It is this accuracy which makes the
acy which makes the International style so hard of achievement in its higher branches; to
higher branches; to hope to get through this list of searching figures, it is clear that the

t is clear that the balance, the pace, and the power of the skater must be in perfect
control. And all the time the
nd all the time the appearance of insouciant freedom is there, though all the time that
h all the time that freedom is bound by laws as relentless as those which regulate the
which regulate the tranquillity of the English style. The feats are so difficult that they
difficult that they cannot be executed except in a certain way, just as the ball that spins

the ball that spins so carelessly over the tennis net cannot win a short chase off the back
wall unless it has been hit in one way and no other.

A further important branch of International skating is the
pair-skating, which ranges from the simple waltz-step to the most
tz-step to the most intricate evolutions. The rhythm and grace of this delightful exhibition
lightful exhibition is beyond all words; beyond all words, too, is the training and skill
training and skill which it implies. Every bar of the music which accompanies it has its
ompanies it has its appropriate movement: it is a perfect song of motion set to the band.
on set to the band. But the beauty and swing of it are things quite indescribable; one might
cribable; one might as well hope to reproduce the dancing of Pavlova in pen and ink as to
n pen and ink as to convey any sense of it to those who have not seen it. And those who have
And those who have seen it would very wisely yawn and pass on if they observed a purple
y observed a purple paragraph on the subject looming ahead. But thistledown is not so light
own is not so light in a warm west breeze, nor the curves of a swallow’s flight more
allow’s flight more deliciously unconjecturable than a well-matched pair in this pastime so

in this pastime so perfectly preconcerted that it looks entirely unrehearsed. On they
drift, gliding, turning, parting to come together again.... Mrs.

ther again.... Mrs. Gummidge, for the moment, would cease to think of the old ’un, and
inquire the price of skates—and knee-pads.

Plate XVI

SKATING-RINK AT CHÂTEAU D’OEX

CHAPTER
III

TEES AND CRAMPITS

These great Swiss rinks, the construction
of which has already been dealt with, are made for the benefit of the
the benefit of the skater and the curler, but wherever possible the curler should be
he curler should be accommodated with a separate rink of his own. Epicure though the skater
e though the skater is, with regard to the smoothness and levelness of his ice, the curler,
is ice, the curler, quite rightly, is even more exigent, and slight slopes of surface and
opes of surface and minute inequalities and roughnesses which do not interfere with the
interfere with the skater at all, make it impossible for the curler to have a satisfactory
have a satisfactory rink. In any case, the curler’s portion must be roped off from the
roped off from the skating part of the rink, for, naturally, no skate blade must make the
blade must make the smallest scratch on his sacred enclosure; while, on the other side, the
the other side, the curler is liable, in the ecstasies of his “sooping,” to shed and scatter
to shed and scatter pieces of broom which wander on to the skater’s ice and cause falls.
ce and cause falls. Besides, the skip habitually shouts at the top of his voice, and a good
s voice, and a good stone evokes choruses of open-throated music: thus, if many curlers are
if many curlers are shouting at the top of their voices, combined skaters cannot hear the
ers cannot hear the caller, unless he shouts at the top of his voice. If he does this while
he does this while skating a figure, he will speedily become purple in the face and quite
the face and quite breathless. Also, the curler smokes when he curls, which tempts the
s, which tempts the skater to do likewise, and for the sake of the rink he must not. For

nk he must not. For those and many other reasons, the curler should, when possible, have
a

en possible, have
a separate rink of his own, where he can soop and shout and smoke without
interfering with anybody.

Now, just as the art of skating has enormously progressed owing to
the facilities afforded by Swiss rinks and winters, so too has that
rs, so too has that great sister art of curling. As in all forms of sport where delicacy or
t where delicacy or “touch” are essential to success, occasional practice is not enough to
ce is not enough to produce really first-rate curlers, or, indeed, to keep the first-rate
keep the first-rate curler at the top of his game; and any who wish to excel must have

to excel must have constant practice, such as Swiss or Canadian winters give him. But
Canada is a far cry to go a-curling, and we may put down the

we may put down the vastly-growing number of curlers, and their growing skill, to the
opportunities afforded by Switzerland. There, all day long, in a
all day long, in a brilliant sun and yet on unsoftened ice, harder and faster than is ever
faster than is ever procurable in English or Scotch winters, the game goes on, and I do not

es on, and I do not know of a single Swiss resort where provision is not made for those who
practise this delightful sport.

Into the history of curling there is not space to penetrate, and we
must, in a treatise of which the range is confined to the present and
to the present and does not explore into the mists of antiquity, confine ourselves to
onfine ourselves to considering the practical aspects of the game. As St. Andrews is to
s St. Andrews is to golf, as the N.S.A. is to skating, or the M.C.C. to cricket, so to
. to cricket, so to curling is the Royal Caledonian Club, whose rules are the acknowledged

re the acknowledged authority on all points in connection with the game. It would take too
much space to give these in extenso, but the following
, but the following extracts, with certain notes, will be found to explain the principles

lain the principles and practice of the game, and enable anyone to construct a standard
rink.

1. The length of the rink for play, viz. from the hack or from the
heel of the crampit to the tee, shall be 42 yards—in no case shall it be
no case shall it be less than 32 yards.

2. The tees shall be 39 yards apart—and, with a tee as the centre, a
circle having a radius of 7 feet shall be drawn. Additional inner
n. Additional inner circles may also be drawn.

3. In alignment with the tees, lines, to be called central lines,
shall be drawn from the tees to points 4 yards behind each tee, and at
nd each tee, and at these points foot scores 18 inches in length shall be drawn at right
l be drawn at right angles, on which, at 6 inches from the central line, the heel of the
ne, the heel of the crampit shall be placed; when, however, in lieu of a crampit a hack is

a crampit a hack is preferred, it shall be made 3 inches from the central line, and not more
than 12 inches in length.

4. Other scores shall be drawn across the rink at right angles to the
central line, as in the diagram, viz.:

(a) A hog score, distant from either tee one-sixth part of
the distance between the “foot score” and the farther tee.

(b) A “sweeping score” across each 7-foot circle and through
each tee.

(c) A “back score” behind and just touching outside the
7-foot circle.

Note.—In these four rules are contained the complete
directions for the marking out of the rink. But as they contain certain

hey contain certain terms of mystic meaning, it may be useful to state them in a less
technical manner.

In other words, then, you start with a point on the ice, which is the
“tee,” and using this as a centre you draw round it a circle of 7-foot
a circle of 7-foot radius. This is done by means of a lath or strip of wood with two nails
wood with two nails or steel points projecting from the lower face, 7 feet apart. Inserting
et apart. Inserting one of these in the centre you pull the lath round, so that the other
, so that the other scratches on the ice a circumference at a distance of 7 feet. As stated
f 7 feet. As stated in Rule 2, “additional circles” may also be drawn. These circles are
. These circles are drawn from the same centre, with a radius of 2½ and 4 feet respectively
4 feet respectively from it. This is done for convenience in measuring the distance from the
e distance from the tee of stones lying within the 7-foot radius, as it gives additional
it gives additional lines of measurement. This whole system of circles with the central tee
ith the central tee is called “the house,” and, as we shall see, all stones which, after
stones which, after being played, have come to rest with any part of them lying within the
em lying within the house, may add to the score of the side which has projected them there.
ojected them there. Behind the house, in the position specified in Rule 3, is placed the
le 3, is placed the crampit. This is a strip of iron long enough for the player to stand on
player to stand on with one foot in advance of the other. It is roughened with spikes on
ened with spikes on its lower side, so that it maintains a firm position on the ice, and at
on the ice, and at the back of it is a ridge against which the player places his right foot
aces his right foot before delivering the stones. It forms, in fact, a firm base for playing
rm base for playing from, since, if anybody attempted to put down a curling-stone, while
urling-stone, while standing on the ice itself, with sufficient velocity to make it slide
ty to make it slide over the 42 yards to the other tee, he would quite certainly slip and
certainly slip and put himself down instead. It is from a crampit that almost all curlers
almost all curlers nowadays play. As an alternative they may use what is in the rule called

in the rule called a “hack,” which is a small iron contrivance fixed to the boot, and which
answers the same

ch
answers the same purpose as a crampit. But it is not, in Switzerland anyhow, often seen,

anyhow, often seen, for it requires adjustment for each individual player, whereas the
crampit fits all alike.

Now this arrangement of hog-score (usually called “the hog”), back
score, sweeping score, “house” and crampit (or hack), scratched in the
), scratched in the ice according to these directions, completes the construction of one end
truction of one end of the rink. At the other end a similar construction is made in
truction is made in alignment, the centre of the two houses being 39 yards from one another.

s from one another. Here is the rink ready for play, and the rest of the rules deal entirely
with the game itself.

Note.—Now I have before me the Rules of the Royal Caledonian
Curling Club of 1911-1912, which, I believe, are the latest. But neither
latest. But neither there nor elsewhere can I find the slightest allusion to the principles
n to the principles of scoring at the game, foreknowledge of which is probably assumed. But
obably assumed. But since it is possible that there are those who do not know how the score
know how the score is made, it is well to state it. Briefly, then, the stone which, at the
stone which, at the end of a “head” or “end” of the match (which is made up by every player
up by every player having had his turn, and having played his two stones), lies nearest to
s), lies nearest to the tee counts one point to the side to which the stone belongs, given
tone belongs, given that it or any part of it lies within the house. If the stone that lies
the stone that lies next nearest to the tee belongs to the same side it counts one also; so
counts one also; so also does the next nearest and the next nearest and the next nearest,
d the next nearest, provided they are all in the house and belong to the same side. But if,
same side. But if, after the stone lying nearest to the tee, the next nearest belongs to
nearest belongs to the opposing side, the first-named counts one, but this second stone

t this second stone takes precedence of all others lying in the house, and the side that
owns the nearest one counts one only. Supposing
one only. Supposing there are two stones which, after measurement, are found to lie exactly

ound to lie exactly equidistant from the tee, the head or end is a draw, and is like a
halved hole at golf.

5. All matches shall be of a certain number of heads or shots or by
time as may be agreed on, or as fixed by an umpire at the outset....

6. Every rink of players shall be composed of four a side, each using
two stones, and no player shall wear boots, tramps, or sandals with
ps, or sandals with spikes or other contrivances which shall break or damage the surface of

mage the surface of the ice. The rotation of play observed during the first head of a match
shall not be changed.

Note.—Players are usually shod with “gouties.” These are
cloth overshoes with india-rubber soles, and are put on over the boot.
t on over the boot. What is required is (by the rule) something that will not injure the
will not injure the ice, while the player for his own sake will wear something that enables
ething that enables him to run with the stone he is sweeping with the least possible risk of
st possible risk of falling down. On the whole, rubber-soled footgear is the best.

7. The skips opposing each other shall settle, by lot or in any other
way they may agree upon, which party shall lead at the first head, after
e first head, after which the winners of the preceding head shall do so.

Note.—The head, as already stated, consists of the
projection of sixteen stones from one crampit towards the house at the
ds the house at the other end of the rink, for each player puts down two stones, and there
o stones, and there are eight players. Then when all have played the head is complete, the
ad is complete, the score is recorded, and the next head is played from the crampit

ed from the crampit behind the house into which they have just been playing. They “cross
over,” that is to say, to the other end of the rink.

The skips (short for skippers) are the captains of the opposing
sides. They have complete control of their sides, and direct each player
direct each player (with due regard for his capabilities) what shot he is to play for. The
is to play for. The skips “toss up” who shall have the choice of beginning (stones being
nning (stones being played by opposing sides alternately), and the side which scores at the
which scores at the first head takes the honour (as at golf) at the second head. If neither
nd head. If neither side scores (the head being halved) the honour remains as it was. It may
s as it was. It may be noted also that though in regular matches (as stated in Rule 5) the
ated in Rule 5) the number of heads to be played is settled beforehand, in an ordinary
and, in an ordinary friendly game it is more usual merely to see how time is going when play

is going when play has been in progress a couple of hours or so, and then determine how
many more heads shall be played.

8. All curling-stones shall be of a circular shape. No stone,
including handle and bolts, shall be of a greater weight than 44 lb.

weight than 44 lb. imperial, or of greater circumference than 36 inches, or of less height
than one-eighth part of its greatest circumference.

Note.—The stones, then, are great granite buns with a handle
to project them by. The usual weight is from about 36 to 40 lb., and the
to 40 lb., and the reason why a limit is given to their weight is that people like Mr.
hat people like Mr. Sandow could doubtless deliver stones which weighed as much as grand
ed as much as grand pianos. These could not be shifted by lighter granite buns, which would

e buns, which would merely recoil from them. Two or three of them would also fill up the
greater part of the fairway of the rink.

9. No stone shall be substituted for another (except under Rules 10
and 14) after the match has begun, but the sole of a stone may be

e of a stone may be reversed at any time during a match, provided the player is ready to
play when his turn comes.

Note.—The question of the reversing of stones is dealt with
later in the practical part of this essay. For the moment it is
or the moment it is sufficient to say that one side of the stone is very highly polished,
ry highly polished, the other less so. When the stone is put down on its highly polished (or
highly polished (or “keen”) side, it will, of course, with the same initial velocity travel

ial velocity travel further than if put down on its rougher (or “dour”) side, the friction
on the ice being less.

10. Should a stone be broken, the largest fragment shall be
considered in the game for that head—the player being entitled to use
ing entitled to use another stone or another pair during the remainder of the match.

11. All stones which roll over, or come to rest on their sides or
tops, shall be removed from the ice.

Note.—So weird a phenomenon seems impossible, but then
curlers are very weird also. Incredible as it may sound, it is quite
sound, it is quite possible to put down one of these great granite buns with the handle in
with the handle in the centre of its top crust so unevenly that, after a drunken wobble or
a drunken wobble or two, it turns right over amid howls and shouts and execrations. Probably
ecrations. Probably you could not do it if you tried, any more than you could cut a
han you could cut a golf-ball smartly to square leg when you mean to go quite straight. But
quite straight. But these distressing feats are known to occur, without the player having
t the player having had the smallest desire to accomplish them. The traditional penalty for
itional penalty for thus mishandling a stone is “drinks all round.” The present writer has

present writer has never seen a stone come to rest on its side, but “credit, quia
impossibile.”

13. Players, during the course of each head, shall be arranged along
the sides, but well off the centre of the rink.... Skips only shall be
Skips only shall be entitled to stand within the seven-foot circle.

14.... Should a player play a wrong stone, any of the players may
stop it while running; but if the mistake is not noticed till the stone

iced till the stone is at rest, the stone which ought to have been played shall be put in
its place, to the satisfaction of the opposing skip.

16. The sweeping shall be under the direction and control of the
skips. The player’s party may sweep the ice from the hog score next the
hog score next the player to the tee, and any stone set in motion by a played stone may be
played stone may be swept by the party to which it belongs. When snow is falling or
snow is falling or drifting, the player’s party may sweep the ice from tee to tee.... Both
tee to tee.... Both skips have equal rights to clean and sweep the ice behind the tee at any
hind the tee at any time, except when a player is being directed by his skip....

Note.—The all-important question of sweeping is dealt with
later. The principle at the base of the rule is that a player’s side may
a player’s side may encourage (or not) his stone to proceed, but the other side may not
other side may not interfere with it in any way at all. In accordance with this principle
with this principle is the direction that says that if a stone during its course moves a

its course moves a stone belonging to the other side, that stone may be swept or left alone
at the option of the other side.

17. (a) If in sweeping or otherwise a running stone is
marred by any of the party to which it belongs, it may, in the option
of the

n the option
of the opposing skip, be put off the ice; but if by any of the adverse party,

the adverse party, it may be placed where the skip of the party to which it belongs shall
direct....

(b) Should any played stone be displaced before the head is
reckoned, it shall be placed as nearly as possible where it lay....

18. No measuring of shots shall be allowed previous to the
termination of the head.

19. The skip shall have the exclusive regulation and direction of the
game for his rink, and may play last stone or any part of the game he

part of the game he pleases.... When his turn to play comes, he shall select one of the
players to act as skip in his place.

22. Every stone shall be eligible to count which is not clearly
outside the seven-foot circle. Every stone which does not clear the
does not clear the hog-score shall be a hog, and must be removed from the ice.... Stones
the ice.... Stones passing the back-score, and lying clear of it, must be removed from the

be removed from the ice, as also any stone which in its progress touches the swept snow on
either side the rink.

Note.—Thus there is only a certain portion of the ice on
which stones may remain during the progress of each “end” or “head.” If
“end” or “head.” If a player sends down a stone too weakly so that it does not reach the
does not reach the hog-score, or so crookedly that it goes into the swept snow at the side
pt snow at the side of the rink, or so strongly that it passes over the back-score, it is at
ack-score, it is at once removed from the ice. But, strangely enough, it is nowhere laid
it is nowhere laid down what the breadth of a rink should be. Somewhat pathetically this
t pathetically this rule presupposes that there is always “swept snow” at the side of the
at the side of the rink, which, happily, is not the case. As a matter of fact the space

r of fact the space allowed for each rink is, roughly speaking, about 20 feet, though I am
not aware that it is laid

are that it is laid down authoritatively anywhere. In any case a stone, to be of the
slightest use, must be lying not so wide as 10 feet (lateral
as 10 feet (lateral measurement) from the tee, and those lying wider, as well as those which
well as those which have definitely passed beyond the back-score, cannot conceivedly come
ot conceivedly come into play, and so may as well be removed. But the case is different with
e is different with stones lying short of the hog-score, and in a straight line between the
ht line between the tees. Such stones, as will be readily understood, might possibly be of
ight possibly be of the utmost value to guard other stones lying in the house, and perhaps
house, and perhaps to be promoted into possible scorers. A guard, then, which is so
, then, which is so important an item, must be put down with some skill, and with requisite
and with requisite strength, and thus it is laid down that stones lying short of the hog
ng short of the hog are considered not to have been sufficiently skilfully played to take

CHAPTER
IV

TOBOGGANING

To descend an ice-run like the Cresta at
St. Moritz is no doubt a most thrilling and skilled adventure, but the
adventure, but the vast majority of people who say (with perfect truth) that they enjoy
th) that they enjoy tobogganing would sooner think of ascending in an aeroplane than
n an aeroplane than descending the Cresta, and would freeze with fright at the thought of
t at the thought of embarking on it. On the other hand, the skilled Cresta runner would no
sta runner would no more think that the quiet descent of snow-covered roads on a Swiss luge
ads on a Swiss luge was tobogganing in his sense of the word, than the aeroplanist would
e aeroplanist would allow that a man practising high jump was flying. From which we may

. From which we may rightly infer that there are various sorts of movement which are covered
by the word tobogganing.

As a matter of fact there are, commonly practised in Switzerland,
three broad and widely differing species of tobogganing. They are as
follows:

(i) Proceeding—quickly or leisurely—down frozen roads or artificial
snow-made runs.

(ii) Proceeding—as quickly as possible—down artificial ice-runs.

(iii) Bobsleighing (or bobbing)—as quickly as possible—down roads or
artificial runs.

The number of folk who practise the first of these immensely
outnumbers those who practise the other two; for everybody in
o; for everybody in Switzerland in the winter is guilty of the first practice, from the
practice, from the small Swiss native, aged perhaps eight or under, who marches up to
, who marches up to school with its books tied on to its luge, and gaily and jauntily
gaily and jauntily returns home seated on it, steering and guiding with its ridiculous
with its ridiculous little feet, and shouting “Gare” or “Achtung,” according to the canton,
ding to the canton, up to the skilled racer on the skeleton who carries off the Symonds bowl
ff the Symonds bowl in the race on the Klosters road at Davos. But all these, different as
these, different as their performances are, are going on snow-runs. The snow may in places,
snow may in places, it is true, where it has thawed and frozen again, intimately resemble
intimately resemble ice. But the ice-run is different in kind from any snow-runs.

For ordinary travel, let us say from your hotel down to the rink,
where there is no question of racing, but just getting there, the
getting there, the toboggan generally used is the Swiss toboggan or luge. It is a high
luge. It is a high wooden frame (high, that is, compared to the skeleton) with two runners
n) with two runners shod with steel or iron, and you sit on it exactly as is most
exactly as is most comfortable—it is never very comfortable—and tie your lunch and skates
ur lunch and skates on to it, and push off. If you want to turn to the right, you put your
right, you put your right heel into the snow, or dab with your hand on the right side; if
the right side; if you want to go to the left, you perform the same operation in a sinister
ation in a sinister manner. If you want to stop, you put both heels into the snow. If you
to the snow. If you want to go quicker, you, while still sitting down, walk with both feet
walk with both feet simultaneously. This sounds complicated; but it is quite clear the

is quite clear the moment you feel you want to go quicker—it is done instinctively.
Finally, if you are going fast, and must make a sudden stop,

Ice-runs

There is one Mecca: there is one St. Peter’s: there is one Cresta. As
is Mecca to the Mohammedan, as is St. Peter’s to the Catholic, so is the
Catholic, so is the Cresta run at St. Moritz to the tobogganer. It is the ice-run.

It is the ice-run. There may be others, and there certainly are, but what does the Cresta
care? It has a cachet which no other possesses.

The Cresta was first engineered, I believe, in the year 1884, and its
chief architect was Herr Peter Badruth of St. Moritz. From that time
itz. From that time onwards it has yearly been built up with as much thought and care as is
ught and care as is lavished on a cathedral; every yard of it is staked out, and the angles,
ut, and the angles, curves, and shaping of its banks and corners most accurately calculated.
urately calculated. It is built up from the bottom upwards, so that the lower part of it can
ower part of it can be used while the construction of the upper part is still going on, and
still going on, and the whole run is generally open not until after the middle of February.
middle of February. Every winter is this amazing architecture in crystal planned and carried

planned and carried out under the direction of Mr. W. H. Bulpett, who has for many years
been chief architect.

To begin with, the snow is trampled down, after the manner of making
the foundation of an ice-rink, so as to form a firm solid base, and

irm solid base, and where the banks are to be built snow is brought in sleigh-loads,
shovelled on to it, and beaten down. More snow will then be still
will then be still required, and again more, till the whole of the banks are solid and of

ks are solid and of the necessary height and curve. Then the banks and the rest of the
course (the straights) are sprinkled with water and
kled with water and again beaten down, and the glazed ice surface begins to be made. When
ns to be made. When this has frozen, water is again sprinkled on it, and again and yet
, and again and yet again, till the whole section has become, banks and course alike, a
and course alike, a surface of smooth hard ice. Down each side of the narrow racing track
narrow racing track (except at its banked corner it is only a few feet wide, a riband of
t wide, a riband of ice) are little walls of firm built snow, also iced, so that the runner,
so that the runner, if he is going moderately straight, cannot leave the track, though he
he track, though he often comes into slight collision with these walls. But even slight
ls. But even slight collisions when travelling at a speed that sometimes exceeds 70 miles an
exceeds 70 miles an hour are not experiences to be encountered unarmed, and the elbows and
and the elbows and knees are thickly protected by felt pads, while on the toes of his boots
e toes of his boots are toothed rakes made of steel, which are used to guide the runner

to guide the runner round the bank and to check his speed if it is so excessive that,
unchecked, he would run over the tops of the banks.

A very high degree of nerve, skill, and judgment is required on such
an ice-run as this. The rider’s object being to cover the course in as
er the course in as few seconds as possible, he must clearly take his banks (i.e.
ake his banks (i.e. get round the curves) with as little loss of speed as possible, and he
as possible, and he will only use his brakes when his judgment tells him that if unchecked
m that if unchecked he would be carried over the top of them. On the other hand, he does not
r hand, he does not want to brake unless it be necessary, and you will often see him with
often see him with his top runners within an inch or two of the edge of these huge sloping
these huge sloping ice-curves. At Battledore and Shuttlecock, the two biggest banks on the
iggest banks on the Cresta, he enters the second immediately after coming out of the first,

g out of the first, and the two form a great S curve. Lower down again, before he threads
the

ON THE CRESTA RUN

From the Drawing by Fleming Williams

arch of the railway bridge, there is another called Bulpett’s corner,
designed to protect him from running out to the left of the course, and
of the course, and then a headlong descent takes him to the winning-post, which is at the
st, which is at the bottom of the hill. Passing this he snaps a thread with an electric
ad with an electric connection, which registers the exact fraction of a second at which he
second at which he passes it. Then, on his run out, he whirls up a steep ice-covered slope,
ice-covered slope, for if this were not iced too, his speed would be so abruptly checked
so abruptly checked that he and his toboggan would be bowled over and over like a shot
nd over like a shot rabbit, and comes to a stop just outside the little village of Cresta.
village of Cresta. But even with this steep slope to check him after his race is over, the
s race is over, the momentum acquired is so great that, if he does not brake heavily all the

ake heavily all the way up this hill, he will, on reaching the level ground at the top,
shoot high into the air, toboggan and all.

Some idea of the speed at which toboggans travel on the straight
reaches of the course may be gathered from the average speed at which
rage speed at which the course can be run. It is over 1300 yards in length, and has been
ength, and has been traversed in a shade over 60 seconds! This means that the highest rate
at the highest rate of speed must be well over 70 miles an hour. This on a pair of steel
on a pair of steel runners, head foremost, with your face a few inches above the solid ice,
bove the solid ice, with nothing to check you except a small-toothed rake on the toe of each

on the toe of each boot! Yet so wonderfully skilful is the construction of the run, so
cunningly is it built to safeguard the headlong traveller, that
ong traveller, that accidents are very few. Two fatal ones, indeed, there have been, but of

e have been, but of these one had nothing to do with the course itself, but was owing to the
fact that a rider started from the top before one of the
p before one of the barriers across the course, which show that it is not open for racing,
ot open for racing, had been removed. In the other, the rider ran over a bank and his
over a bank and his toboggan fell on the top of him. One of the great difficulties which the
ficulties which the builders and managers of this run, in company with other ice-runs, have
ther ice-runs, have to contend against, is the power of the sun. It is, of course,
. It is, of course, absolutely necessary that the icing of the run should be so solid that
ld be so solid that there is no chance of the runner of a toboggan going through it, which
g through it, which would naturally mean a bad spill. But it is also necessary that certain
essary that certain of the banks must have the sun blazing into them all day long, which
all day long, which would cause them to lose ice faster than it could be made by the
ould be made by the sprinkling which goes on when the sun is off them. At such points,
em. At such points, therefore, big canvas screens are put up, which shade the bank from the
e the bank from the direct rays; also tobogganing is never permitted to go on all day. It
o go on all day. It starts early in the morning, when the run has been recuperated by the
recuperated by the night of frost, and is closed when, in the opinion of the management,

of the management, the sun has so softened the banks that there is danger of a toboggan
cutting through the crust.

Bobsleighing
(or Bobbing)

This charming form of the sport may be described as combined
tobogganing, and in bobbing races teams of four enter against each
enter against each other. The form of toboggan used is, of course, immensely larger than

mensely larger than that employed in single tobogganing, since it will hold five or six
persons, and its construction is altogether different and most

different and most elaborate. It consists of a long, low platform some
10 feet in length, and is mounted, not on one pair of runners, but on
of runners, but on two. The pair that supports the fore part of the bobsleigh is a sort of
sleigh is a sort of bogie-truck, pivoted under the platform, and it can be turned to the
an be turned to the right and left in order to direct the course of the bob round curves.
e bob round curves. This turning of it is done by the captain, who sits first at the bows of
irst at the bows of the sleigh, and is worked by ropes, which he holds in his hands, or by a
his hands, or by a wheel which controls its movements. In long runs, as on the Schatz-alp
s on the Schatz-alp at Davos, the wheel is far better than the ropes, since it entails so
since it entails so much less strain on the hands of the steersman: on a short run the ropes
short run the ropes are as good. Behind the captain sit the members of his crew in line,
f his crew in line, with the loops of rope just outside the framework of the sleigh, in
k of the sleigh, in which they fix their heels. Last of them all sits the brakesman, at the
e brakesman, at the stern of the sleigh, who has in his control a powerful steel-toothed
erful steel-toothed brake, which crosses the sleigh behind and is worked with levers. But it
with levers. But it is the captain who is in command of the bob, and the brakesman and other
brakesman and other members of the crew only perform his orders. The word “bobsleigh” is
word “bobsleigh” is derived from the movement of leaning or “bobbing” forward, which is done
ward, which is done by all the crew together, to get up speed or increase it. They come

rease it. They come forward quickly with a jerk, and go back again slowly and steadily, and
this without doubt accelerates the movement of the sleigh.

As in all other forms of tobogganing, braking is employed to diminish
speed in coming to corners, where otherwise the momentum would cause the

tum would cause the whole concern to leave the track altogether. So also, just as the
ice-tobogganer inclines his body
r inclines his body inwards in a similar position, the captain and crew lean to the inside
lean to the inside of the track when going round a corner so as to help the toboggan round
the toboggan round it, while the inclination of the front pair of runners is directed to
ners is directed to the same end. By strong leaning inwards, combined with the inclination
ith the inclination of the bogie-pair of runners, quite considerable curves may be taken at
ves may be taken at high velocity without the use of the brake at all, and the consequent
and the consequent loss of speed. But all this is left to the judgment of the captain, who
of the captain, who has to decide whether by direction of the bogie-runners alone, or by
unners alone, or by that in conjunction with the leaning inwards of his crew, he can safely
crew, he can safely negotiate a corner without calling for the use of the brake. And the
the brake. And the responsibility is entirely in his hands. At the same time much depends
e time much depends on the prompt obedience of the crew to his orders, for it is easily
s, for it is easily possible that a corner might have been safely coasted round if they had
d round if they had obeyed his call to lean inwards, which would spill them all if his call
hem all if his call was not immediately responded to. How great the effect of this inward
fect of this inward shifting of the weight can be, if it is thoroughly carried out, may be
carried out, may be guessed from Plate XXXI. In this same photograph the inward direction of
inward direction of the front pair of runners may also be seen assisting the work of the

ing the work of the crew. And it is this “teamwork,” the sense of working in unison under
orders, which gives much of its charm to bobbing. Everyone
o bobbing. Everyone feels—rightly—that much of the success of the run depends on his

run depends on his individual work, even though his individual work is only to lean as far
as possible out of the bob without parting company with it
ing company with it altogether.

Bobbing can be practised on an ordinary road covered with hard snow,
or, in excelsis, on runs constructed for this express

which starts by the Bandy rink and finishes side by side with the Cresta
ide with the Cresta ice-run, after passing under the railway bridge, and the Schatz-alp run
the Schatz-alp run at Davos. Previous to its construction, not many years ago, bobbing at
ars ago, bobbing at Davos chiefly took place on the Klosters road, which was the same track
was the same track as that used by the ordinary toboggan, but now each has its own course.
has its own course. These artificially constructed bob-runs are engineered with the same
eered with the same care and nicety as ice-runs for the single toboggan, and at corners
gan, and at corners curved banks are built solidly of beaten-down snow. The track is then
. The track is then iced, for no snow could stand the continual passage of the heavy bobs
e of the heavy bobs over the same banks and narrow course without speedily being worn into
ily being worn into ruts that would entirely spoil the going and upset the goers, and the
the goers, and the ice is then sprinkled over with loose snow to prevent the toboggan
revent the toboggan skidding. But the greater part of bobbing is done on the public roads,
n the public roads, which are frozen and hardened by the passage of sleighs. At most Swiss

ighs. At most Swiss winter resorts there are facilities for this delightful form of

CHAPTER
V
ICE-HOCKEY

Many of the Swiss winter-resorts can put
into the field a very strong ice-hockey team, and fine teams from other
ne teams from other countries often make winter tours there; but the ice-hockey which the
ce-hockey which the ordinary winter visitor will be apt to join in will probably be of the
probably be of the most elementary and unscientific kind indulged in, when the skating day

hen the skating day is drawing to a close, by picked-up sides. As will be readily
understood, the ice over which a hockey match has been played is
has been played is perfectly useless for skaters any more that day until it has been swept,
it has been swept, scraped, and sprinkled or flooded; and in consequence, at all Swiss
uence, at all Swiss resorts, with the exception of St. Moritz, where there is a rink that
here is a rink that has been made for the hockey-player, or when an important match is being
tant match is being played, this sport is supplementary to such others as I have spoken of.
s I have spoken of. Nobody, that is, plays hockey and nothing else, since he cannot play
ince he cannot play hockey at all till the greedy skaters have finished with the ice.

And in most places hockey is not taken very seriously: it is a
charming and heat-producing scramble to take part in when the out-door
n when the out-door day is drawing to a close and the chill of the evening beginning to set
ng beginning to set in; there is a vast quantity of falling down in its componence and not

componence and not very many goals, and a general ignorance about rules. But since a game,
especially such a wholly admirable
a wholly admirable and delightful game as ice-hockey, may just as well be played on the
ll be played on the lines laid down for its conduct as not, I append at the end of this

at the end of this short section a copy of the latest edition of the rules as issued by
Prince’s Club, London.

For the rest, everybody knows the “sort of thing” hockey is, and
quite rightly supposes that ice-hockey is the same “sort of thing”
ame “sort of thing” played on a field of ice by performers shod in skates. As is natural,
tes. As is natural, the practice and ability which enable a man to play ordinary hockey with
rdinary hockey with moderate success are a large factor in his success when he woos the more
en he woos the more elusive sister-sport; another factor, and one which is not sufficiently
is not sufficiently appreciated, is the strength of his skating. It is not enough to be able
t enough to be able to run very swiftly on the skates: no one is an ice-hockey player of the
ockey player of the lowest grade who cannot turn quickly to right or left, start quickly,
eft, start quickly, and above all, stop quickly. However swift a player may be, he is
layer may be, he is practically useless to his side unless he can, with moderate suddenness,

oderate suddenness, check his headlong career, turn quickly, and when the time comes again
start quickly.

I have often been asked whether ice-hockey is “bad” for skating. Most
emphatically it is not: on the other hand, it is extremely good for most
emely good for most skaters, since it gives them strength of ankle and accustoms them to
d accustoms them to move at a high speed. Strength, as we have seen before, is not the prime
e, is not the prime need of a skater, but balance: strength, however, is a most useful
r, is a most useful adjunct. But though hockey is good for the skater, he will certainly
, he will certainly find that he will not skate well or accurately immediately after playing

ately after playing hockey, any more than he will skate well the moment he has taken off his
skis. But the

f his
skis. But the feeling that to play hockey unfits the skater for that which he may
regard as his more artistic job, is, as far as can be seen,
far as can be seen, unfounded.

It is a wonderful and delightful sight to watch the speed and
accuracy of a first-rate team, each member of which knows the play of
h knows the play of the other five players. The finer the team, as is always the case, the
lways the case, the greater is their interdependence on each other, and the less there is of
he less there is of individual play. Brilliant running and dribbling, indeed, you will see;
deed, you will see; but as distinguished from a side composed of individuals, however good,
uals, however good, who are yet not a team, these brilliant episodes are always part of a
re always part of a plan, and end not in some wild shot but in a pass or a succession of
or a succession of passes, designed to lead to a good opening for scoring. There is,

scoring. There is, indeed, no game at which team play outwits individual brilliance so
completely.

But such is not the aspect of the game that will strike the observer
who watches the usual pick-up or inter-hotel match on the rink, which
on the rink, which generally begins as soon as skaters hear the curfew of the tea-bell.
ew of the tea-bell. Here will be found the individualist who, sooner than pass when he has
an pass when he has once got the puck, would infinitely prefer to fall and be trampled on;
and be trampled on; and you will see him, while still sitting on the ice, hacking wildly at
, hacking wildly at the beloved india-rubber, in flat contravention of the rule. Common,
f the rule. Common, too, are the “non-stops” (like Wimbledon trains) who, once having got up
once having got up speed, are practically brakeless. Indeed, it was in connection with

in connection with non-stops that the present writer saw the most ludicrously comic
incident that it has ever been his good luck to encounter in these

encounter in these winter places, where so many funny things happen. And it was in this
manner. A round dozen of these delightful nonstops
delightful nonstops had made up a hockey match. The rink where they played bounded on three
ed bounded on three sides by snow-banks; on the fourth, at the edge of which was one of
of which was one of their goals, an extremely steep descent (caused by the levelling up of
the levelling up of the ground to make the rink), about 15 feet in height, plunged into the
t, plunged into the snow-covered field below. It was a very cold afternoon, and (so rightly)
n, and (so rightly) the two gentlemen who were deputed to keep goal preferred to plunge into
rred to plunge into the fray and go for the puck whenever they could catch sight of it. In
tch sight of it. In general, there were some four or five out of the twelve players on their
ve players on their feet simultaneously: the rest were momentarily prone. All this was

prone. All this was delightful enough, but I had no conception how funny they were all going
to be.

It so happened that the puck was in the neighbourhood of the goal
away from the steep bank down into the field: it so happened, also, that
appened, also, that all the twelve were on their feet. Somebody in the mélêe near the goal
mélêe near the goal hit the puck with such amazing violence that it flew half-way down the
w half-way down the rink. The whole field, with ever-increasing velocity, poured after it,
y, poured after it, spreading out on both sides of it. Another whack brought it close to the
ght it close to the goal at the edge of the steep bank, and again at top-speed every player

-speed every player on the field was in pursuit. Faster and ever faster they neared the
goal: somebody, with stick high uplifted in the manner of a
in the manner of a three-quarter swing at golf, made a prodigious hit at it, but completely
it, but completely missed it. The next moment every single one of those players had poured
players had poured like a resistless cataract down the steep snow-slope into the field
lope into the field below, leaving the rink completely untenanted except for a small

except for a small innocent-looking puck, which lay a few yards in front of a yawning
goal.

ICE HOCKEY

From the Drawing by Fleming Williams

For a little while this impressive stillness and depopulation lasted.
Then the first “strayed reveller” returned, heavily limping. He took his
imping. He took his time, and with a superb, lightning-like shot sent the puck whirling
t the puck whirling through the unguarded goal. Simultaneously he sat down. Simultaneously a
n. Simultaneously a second player showed his head over the ice-bank and shouted “Offside!”
shouted “Offside!” Simultaneously also, the puck hit him in the face. It is hard to

face. It is hard to believe, I know; but I assure the reader that it was harder to stop
laughing.

At any rate, here are the rules:

Rules of Match Play

1. The puck shall be made of india-rubber, 3 inches in diameter, 1
inch thick, and shall weigh 1¼ lbs., or shall be of such other size or
such other size or shape as shall from time to time be decided.

The stick shall be so made that it can pass through a ring 3 inches
in diameter.

2. The goal-posts at each end of the ice shall be 4 feet high and 4
feet apart.

3. The team shall consist of six players.

4. The goal is scored when the puck passes between the
goal-posts.

5. The game shall consist of two halves of 20 minutes each. The teams
change goals at half-time.

6. The match is won by the team who scores the greater number of
goals. If, when time is called, the number of goals is
number of goals is the same on both sides, the match is said to be a tie. Five minutes each

. Five minutes each way must then be played until the tie is decided, or the teams may
arrange another match.

7. A referee shall be appointed whose duty it shall be to decide all
disputed points, and his decision shall be final.

He shall appoint, if possible, four goal umpires, two at each
end.

The referee shall have power to stop the game for any cause and for
such time as he shall think fit.

In the case of unfair or rough play he shall caution the offender,
and if the offence is repeated, he may order the offender off the ice
ffender off the ice for a certain interval, or for the rest of the match.

If no referee is appointed, the captains shall arbitrate all
disputes.

8. The game shall be started by placing the puck between two opposing
players on the half-way line in the centre of the ice; the sticks of the
; the sticks of the two players must meet three times before either may touch the puck.

may touch the puck. After a goal the puck shall be placed in the centre of the ring and
restarted as above.

9. When the puck goes off the ice, it shall be restarted as in Rule
8, and from a point 3 yards from the side where it left the ice. In case
ft the ice. In case the puck leaves the ice behind the goal line, it shall be restarted at a
l be restarted at a point 5 yards from the goal line and 3 yards from the side.

10. No charging, crossing, riding off, pushing or tripping is
allowed.

11. The player may not raise his stick above his shoulder.

12. No player may carry, stand on, kick or throw the puck
except the goalkeeper, who may kick it, catch it, or knock it away with
knock it away with his hand or leg, or stop it with any part of his body.

13. A player having fallen is considered hors de combat, and
may take no part in the game until he has regained his feet and his
stick.

14. Should the game be stopped by the referee by reason of the
infringement of any of the rules, or because of an accident or change of
cident or change of players, the puck shall be started at the spot where it was last played

it was last played before the infringement, accident or change of players shall have
occurred.

15. No player shall play a forward pass unless at the time of his so
doing there are not less than two of his opponents (including the
ents (including the goalkeeper) between him and the opponents’ goal line (the goal line for
(the goal line for this purpose being an imaginary line drawn from the goal-posts to the
e goal-posts to the side). In the event of such forward pass being played by or hitting such
by or hitting such player as aforesaid, or of his interfering with the game in any way, the

ame in any way, the puck shall be restarted at the point where such forward pass was
made.

16. In the case of one of the players being disabled, the captain of
the opposing team may decide whether he will allow a substitute or take
substitute or take out one man from his own side.

17. No alteration shall be made in the rules unless it be supported
by at least two-thirds of those present at a Special General Meeting
ial General Meeting called for the purpose, of which at least seven days’ notice must be

ays’ notice must be given in writing to each member, or by seven days’ notice posted on the
Club Notice Board—the suggested
Board—the suggested alterations to accompany any such notice or to be affixed to the Club
affixed to the Club Notice Board. Any amendment to be brought forward at such Special

ard at such Special General Meeting must be signed by the proposer and sent to the Hon.
Secretary at least four days before the date of such Special
ate of such Special Meeting.

CHAPTER
VI

SKI-ING

Of all the hundreds of folk who yearly
spend a few weeks or, if they are excessively fortunate or opulent, more
te or opulent, more than a few weeks in Alpine resorts during the winter, there are many who

there are many who devote themselves almost entirely to one sport. Thus you may, as a rule,
never meet a man except on:

Weather bad for his particular branch of sport may temporarily drive
him to another and slightly despised diversion, but when possible, where
hen possible, where his heart is, there will his legs be also. He will be adopting one
ill be adopting one particular method of sliding (I count curling a method of sliding,
method of sliding, because your object is to make your curling-stones slide in a definite
slide in a definite manner) to the exclusion of others, and sliding in some form or other,
some form or other, whether on skates or toboggan or skis, lies at the base of all winter
base of all winter sports. That is why we all go to Switzerland in the winter, because
the winter, because there we find frozen water (or hope to) in abundance. We then, having

ce. We then, having fixed on the particular and hazardous manner in which we wish to slide
over frozen water, with
frozen water, with steel blades or long wooden shoes, proceed to do so. In all cases the
o. In all cases the desire to slide instead of walk regulates the choice of our holiday.
ice of our holiday. Exclusive tobogganers we must regard as a comparative rarity, for there
e rarity, for there are few who practise tobogganing whenever possible and nothing else at

and nothing else at all. As a rule, tobogganers do not toboggan for the whole of every day.
It entails too much hill-climbing.

But of these three classes, I think the confirmed and inoculated
skier is most absolutely wedded to his sport. You will find him a rarer
ll find him a rarer visitor to either form of rink than is the inoculated skater or curler
ed skater or curler to the ski-ing slopes. It will often happen, also, that the inoculated
that the inoculated curler visits the skating-rinks, or the inoculated skater the house and
kater the house and the hog. But the man who comes out to Switzerland in order to ski very
n order to ski very seldom visits either. For various and intricate as are the manœuvres
s are the manœuvres which the expert can perform on skates, and various as are the movements
s are the movements which the expert can cause his curling-stones to perform, there is at
erform, there is at the command of the skier a greater expanse of conquerable territory. Not
able territory. Not only has he his figures, so to speak, to cut on the snow-fields, his
he snow-fields, his Telemark and Christiania swings, and his stemming turns, which
emming turns, which correspond roughly to the threes and rockers and change of edge in the
ange of edge in the skater’s art, and the outwicks and inwicks of the curler, but he has his
ler, but he has his travel over the snows for travel’s sake: he is an artist in climbing,
artist in climbing, and the whole horizon (omitting such mountain peaks as the Matterhorn or
s the Matterhorn or the Aiguilles) are part of his rink, which reaches, broadly speaking,

, broadly speaking, wherever there is snow. And some part of his rink, however bad the
weather, is pretty certain to

The first difficulties that beset the beginner must be considered as

Then it seems that the climber has got tired of his zigzags, and

Now all these devices, the stamping of the skis, the stopping of the

Here he will find careful analyses of ski-ing manœuvres, clearly and

To return to our forlorn beginner on the slope, who has seen vanish

. And here the tyro should surely find encouragement, for he will observe that they often
rve that they often stagger, fall, and are smothered in snow. That does not in the slightest

alise that falling, even in the case of experts, is part of the day’s work, and, as a rule,
rk, and, as a rule, does not hurt at all. Indeed the skier who does not fall is either so
t fall is either so cautious a performer that he cannot be called a skier in any sense of

and demigods make shots of the most putrescent nature.

But as he watches he will notice that these ladies and gentlemen who
are ski-ing are busy not with merely descending the slope they

ticular manner, and interspersing their descent with certain definite manœuvres. Sometimes,
nœuvres. Sometimes, perhaps, one who has climbed into the gully out of which the first

ill also be upright because there is no bend in his knees or hips or neck. In other words,
ck. In other words, he will be standing at right angles to the slope, though leaning
ope, though leaning forward. His skis will be quite close together, so that they make but
that they make but one track in the snow, and his right foot probably will be a few inches
ill be a few inches in front of his left. His arms will be a little raised, so that his
raised, so that his sticks, which swing pendulum-like from his hands, do not touch the snow,
not touch the snow, and his descent is that of a stooping hawk. A spray of fine snow rises
of fine snow rises round the toes of his skis, like the feather of water round the bows of
r round the bows of some lightning-speeded boat. A moment ago he was but a speck high up on
a speck high up on the mountain-side, the next he is but a speck at the end of the slope
he end of the slope below. If not so fortunate, he is somewhere in the middle of that
the middle of that sudden-spouting billow of snow that mars the smooth whiteness of the
th whiteness of the hill. But in any case, the beginner has seen a specimen of ordinary
pecimen of ordinary straight-running, the figure upright and inclined forward, the skis
d forward, the skis close together, with sinecure for the sticks. And if our beginner’s
d if our beginner’s courage is high, he will instantly attempt, from the more gradual slope
more gradual slope on which he stands, to do the same. Probably, if he remembers to ape
he remembers to ape this flying Mercury in the points mentioned, he will progress quite a
ll progress quite a considerable number of yards at his sedater speed without falling. Then
thout falling. Then a wild panic will seize him at the thought that his pace is steadily
is pace is steadily increasing, and that he has not the slightest idea how to check it. That
w to check it. That thought alone will most likely be sufficient so to unsteady him that he
nsteady him that he will instantly fall down and find that he has grasped one method,
grasped one method, anyhow, of stopping. He may then employ the few moments’ pause that
moments’ pause that invariably succeed a tumble to observing whether, from the tracks his
from the tracks his skis have left, he has kept his feet together. If he has, he may feel
he has, he may feel justifiably pleased with himself, but must not be discouraged if the

Then comes another descender. He is going quite straight also, but he
appears merely to be strolling down the same slope that the other fellow
at the other fellow flew down. Yet he does not use his sticks to lean on, but stands upright
but stands upright also, but with toes pointed inwards, legs apart, and heels pointing

This time the question of the technique of getting up obtrudes
itself. Probably his skis are still lovingly entwined together, and,

rror if told that I had to go over even a very mild ski-jump, and probably be found hiding

an impression of it as it strikes the observer.

e the jump has been erected. This is a long steep hillside, and the platform for the jump
atform for the jump has been put up some hundred yards from the top of it. It is a champion
t. It is a champion jumper who has arrived, and the apparatus is on the big scale. Out from

manner of a dormer window in a house-roof or a header-board above a pool. It is made of
wooden planks supported on posts, and covered with a layer of

ards it from above; below the hillside is considerably steeper, and continues at a steep

ce after his flight through the air. The reason of this is that it is absolutely essential
bsolutely essential that the jumper should have no check when he touches ground again after
ground again after his flight: if he landed in soft or deep snow he would quite certainly
uld quite certainly have a bad fall. But with hard smooth snow to land on there is no such
on there is no such check, and on landing he continues his course at high speed straight
high speed straight down the hill. It is also extremely important for him to land on a steep
to land on a steep slope; for if the slope was but gentle, the shock of coming in contact

aving them standing in the snow (for no jumper uses sticks when he jumps, which would be

ith all the impetus that his run and his spring have given him. For a hundred feet or more

“BLOW, BLOW, THOU WINTER WIND”

CHAPTER
VIII

FOR PARENTS AND GUARDIANS

I have attempted in the foregoing pages to
give some general account of the out-door sports which are, as a rule,
ich are, as a rule, indulged in by altitudinists in winter. But any picture of this
any picture of this enchanting Swiss life, however slight, would be imperfect without some
erfect without some allusion to other entertainments which take place between sunset and
between sunset and sunrise. As a matter of fact, there are a good many such, and at most
y such, and at most Swiss resorts there is in one hotel or another a dance, or a fancy-dress

e, or a fancy-dress ball, or a concert, or very often more than one of these, practically
nightly.

Now this piece of information, which I have thus baldly set down (for
I do not believe in the gradual breaking of bad news), will, I am aware,
, will, I am aware, strike a species of terror into many middle-aged and austere breasts.
nd austere breasts. There are large quantities of folk who would sooner die than dance, and
die than dance, and who would feel themselves affronted if, at the end of an active day out
f an active day out of doors, they were expected to sit in rows and be sung to or amused, or
ng to or amused, or even worse, were expected to sing or amuse. At the most, they think they
st, they think they would desire merely to sit quietly and read or converse, or perhaps
onverse, or perhaps occupy a morose corner in a card-room, and the thought of being kept
ought of being kept awake after they have retired to their early beds by the sound of

eds by the sound of bands or dancers would rouse them to a state of frenzied rage. As for
dancing themselves——

Now, I hasten to add words of consolation for all sedate folk. There
is not the slightest need for them to be apprehensive, for they will
sive, for they will find their quiet corners and card-rooms provided for them, unraided by
r them, unraided by the frivolous, and nobody wants them to dance and sing unless they feel
ng unless they feel inclined to. They have an erroneous notion, from hearing enthusiastic
earing enthusiastic young friends on their return from Switzerland say that they had a dance
at they had a dance every night, often fancy-dress, except when there was an ice-carnival or

an ice-carnival or a concert, that they are expected to appear as Pierrots or Columbines,
or otherwise cover themselves with shame and glory by public
and glory by public performances of some such kind, or, after dinner, sally forth again with
ly forth again with a false nose and tights and proceed to dash about the skating-rink among
skating-rink among squibs and fireworks. But there is no kind of reason why they should

son why they should harbour any such fears; they can be as quiet and sedentary as they
like.

But the probability is that they will not, when they have become
altitudinists, feel quite so sedentary as they do in, let us say,
do in, let us say, Cromwell Road, after the day’s work in town. Without doubt there is
hout doubt there is something slightly intoxicating to the mind, some sort of juvenile
me sort of juvenile effervescence in the air and the sun of these high places, which seems
places, which seems to affect the steadiest head, and it is not uncommon to see sober
common to see sober persons of middle-age capering about in a manner altogether surprising.
ogether surprising. They get a sudden access of youth and high spirits, and make themselves

and make themselves ridiculous (this would be their judgment on themselves while still in
Cromwell Road) with

Cromwell Road) with immense enjoyment and élan. Probably in Cromwell Road they
would never dream, for instance, if there was a fall of snow, of making

of snow, of making a snow-man in the back-garden, even if the snow was not covered with
smuts, but out here if by chance a heavy fall renders rink and
ll renders rink and toboggan-run impracticable for the moment, they are perfectly likely
re perfectly likely (they will not believe me, but it is quite true) to build up a sumptuous
uild up a sumptuous piece of statuary. Similarly, unaccustomed as they are to go out of
ey are to go out of doors on a winter’s night after dinner, except to be taken in a taxi to
taken in a taxi to the theatre, it is quite probable that they will don coats and gouties
n coats and gouties and see what is going on at this absurd ice-carnival, which they have

al, which they have been told is to take place on the rink. And really it is almost worth
seeing, even if you take no part in it.

A circle of light from hundreds of electric lamps, or a less potent
but more variously-coloured illumination from lines of Chinese lanterns,
f Chinese lanterns, surrounds the rink, so that in that blaze of light the great
of light the great frosty-burning stars are invisible in the vault overhead, and even the
rhead, and even the full moon seems no more luminous than a circle of pale yellow paper.
pale yellow paper. These are reflected, wherever there is room for reflection, on the ice
lection, on the ice they enclose, but there is not very much room for anything, as the whole
thing, as the whole surface of the rink is covered with brilliant, gaily-dressed figures
ily-dressed figures gliding about in some interval of the dancing. Each carries a Chinese

h carries a Chinese lantern on a stick, and the whole place is an intricate pattern of
interweaving lights and colours. Then the band rings out again
and rings out again (“ringing” is the only word that the least describes the sound of

cribes the sound of violins and horns in this resonant frosty air), and instantly this sheet
of weaving light and figures
g light and figures begins to be permeated by rhythm. Couple by couple are swept into this
are swept into this rhythm, circling, oscillating with long gliding steps, their lanterns
eps, their lanterns making a series of luminous loops as they swing to the measure of the
the measure of the dance. What was but a company of mysterious, huge fire-flies, all
uge fire-flies, all darting about on separate businesses, is turned into a rhythmical and
to a rhythmical and living pattern of flame, controlled by the lilt and measure of the band.
easure of the band. Eye and ear alike are dazzled by this musical and moving and illuminated
ing and illuminated rhythm. Faster grows the tune as it approaches its end, faster is formed
d, faster is formed this living and luminous pattern. Then it stops, and the pattern
ps, and the pattern dissolves itself again into streaks of darting lights; the dance of the
s; the dance of the uncontrolled fire-flies again. And it is far from unlikely that the

m unlikely that the middle-aged and sedate will hurry back to the hotel to get some skates
and a lantern, and some sort of preposterous headgear.

Or, while still the fireworks and Bengal lights are unlit, you can
walk to the end of the rink, and, turning your back on its brightness,
on its brightness, look out over the lower valley below and the hills beyond. Away from the
yond. Away from the glare of the festooned lights, your eye gets accustomed to the gloom,
tomed to the gloom, and presently it ceases to be gloom at all. Ivory white shine the
ory white shine the untrodden snows beneath the full moon and the glory of innumerable
lory of innumerable stars: far below, perhaps, a level sea of cloud extends like a marble
tends like a marble floor over the valley, and across it the aiguilles of Mont Blanc, and
of Mont Blanc, and nearer the summits of the Dent du Midi stand sparkling like crystals.
ling like crystals. Then from behind you sounds the swish of an aspiring rocket, and across

rocket, and across the firmament streams a line of light. Slower and slower it mounts, then
from the end of it bursts a huge constellation of coloured
